characters: ON CHUBBY, PONYTAIL AND CARRIER NAMED DREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jagged mountains defy a dark, foreboding sky. We hear PLODDING HOOVES, CREAKING LEATHER. A lone wanderer appears. Wearing a long coat and a battered hat, he carries a bolt-action carbine. His name forgotten, history remembers him simply as THE POSTMAN. His laden pack mule, BILL, BRAYS, as they pass a battered sign: "The Great Salt Lake Marina." They start down a slope and begin to cross a...

dialogues.speaker: DRY LAKE BED
dialogues.text: A bizarre, wind-swept sight. Dozens of boats resting lee- to on the dry, cracked earth. It's like God pulled the plug. Rusty mooring chains snake their way around house boats, ski boats and a cabin cruiser or two.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The last of the great cities died when my father was a child. Another victim of yet another war. The plagues followed. And the terrors. The living hid themselves away in tiny hamlets in hopes of surviving whatever new madness conspired to rob them of the little that remained. The Earth itself had fallen prey to chaos. For three years a dirty snow fell that even summer could not erase. The ocean was barren. Poisoned. Near death. As The Postman continues to cross, the CAMERA PULLS BACK. He's soon lost in the massive vista.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sixteen long years passed before the great lungs started working again. My father said it was as if the ocean breathed a great sigh of relief... A RUMBLE of THUNDER. RAIN begins to fall. The earth just sucks it up at first, but it's coming hard. Rivulets run. Puddles form. We begin to get the feeling that soon these boats will be tugging at the mooring chains once again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK a rivulet as it runs, filling up a depression in th sand. And then, running to fill another in a series of depressions. They make a pattern we recognize as!--

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S FOOTPRINTS
dialogues.text: These tracks may already be days old as they fill with rain water. Then, the sound of light, padded FOOTFALLS. A LION ENTERS FRAME. Lean, hungry and dangerous, the big cat has been tracking this man. He lets out a low, disappointed GROWL. The rain has foiled his dinner plans!-- for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bullet-ridden sign reads: "U.S. 84 North." The Postman leads Bill down a barren 4-lane. Weeds poke up through the asphalt. The rusting hulk of a car rests in the median, covered in a tangle of purple wisteria. The Postman plucks a flower. He sticks it into a buttonhole and continues. BILL BRAYS woefully. In answer:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. And if you ask me again, I'm going to slug you. They near a sign: "Thank You For Visiting Utah." The Postman waves, shouts to the sign as he passes it.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: It's been fun, hasn't it, kids? (to the sign) You're welcome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill tugs up weeds as The Postman is climbing up a ladder on a highway that razor cuts the plains to the horizon. Above, The Postman sands atop a billboard catwalk. He references a tattered road atlas, scans the horizon through binoculars with one broken lens. He pauses at a Union 76 ball just visible above the tree line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 76 Station and the remains of a Howard Johnson's. Alert, carbine in hand, The Postman leads in the mule. Rusting cars sag on flattened tires. There's a stripped fire engine, its cracked hoses leading to the HoJo foundation which bristles with burned timbers. Bill stops to drink out of a stream. The Postman swats at him with his hat.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Damnit, Bill, you know I need to check it first! Bill hangs his head. The Postman digs through his pack. He removes an old Tupperware container and replaces its contents -- a tiny sheaf of litmus papers and several small bottles -- with stream water. He adds a few drops from each bottle. Swirls it around. Then dips a tiny strip of paper into the water. The paper turns a vivid purple. The Postman is dubious.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Better than turpentine. (touches some to his lips) Tastes about the same. Your call, Bill. Bill drinks.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You ain't picky, Bill. I like that about you. The Postman takes his carbine and a burlap sack and crosses to the 76 Station. An old extension ladder on the ground. The pole holding up the 76 ball has a 30-degree bend in it, like someone once tried to pull it over. Beyond the 76 ball, the sun sets -- but we here in the 20th Century have never seen such a wild riot of color before. The Postman tries the station door. Locked. Smiling ironically, he steps in through the blown-out window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shambles. The Postman kicks around the table. He finds a few beat-up CDs, flips through them. Reads the label. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: ‘Running on Empty’? Tell me about it. Tossing it, he turns, stops. There, resting on a pile of trash is a bashed-in portable TV. The Postman smiles.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Bill! We got TV! 147 channels. Everything from Jesus to ‘Jeopardy’. He steps over, switches on the set. Nothing happens, but The Postman pretends just the same. He mimics static, then:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: ‘Like sands through the hour- glass, so are the days of our lives...' (switching channels) ‘Michael Shields, come on down, you're the next contestant on...'The Price is Right'.' (switching again) I'll take Domestic Nuclear Disasters for two hundred thousand, Alex... The Postman stops suddenly. Click.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: We interrupt our regularly scheduled program to bring you the Second Civil War... Well, shit. The Postman stares at the blank screen a moment. There's a sudden, panicked RUSTLING from behind the service manager's desk. The Postman wheels around, raises the carbine.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't want any trouble I bet you don't either... Let's just call it a draw, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sudden MOVEMENT. The Postman shouts in surprise as a Doe dashes out from behind the desk. Scared, it bounds back and forth between the walls. Then freezes in the corner. The Postman sighs in relief, lowers the carbine.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Look out, Bill! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doe bolts for the window and runs right into Bill. Bill has a conniption fit. Investigating further, The Postman spots a cigarette machine. The front glass is smashed and all the slots are empty. But he looks down to the lock at the bottom. It's intact. He pulls a crowbar from the sack, crouches by the machine and digs the pry into a seam and pulls. The panel bursts open to reveal four half-open cartons of cigarettes. He doesn't believe it for a second. Then:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embers of a campfire glow. The Postman is asleep, the carbine in reach. BILL BRAYS and nervously stamps his hooves. The Postman reaches for the carbine only to find the barrel of a shotgun pointed in his face. Three BANDITS! Hard-eyed and ugly. One, barely 20, is mostly just ugly. The Postman looks down the barrels of a shotgun, a rifle and a revolver. The LEAD BANDIT kicks the carbine out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm just passing through. I don't mean anyone any harm. (re: stream) Water's good. The Lead Bandit pokes at The Postman's shoulder with the muzzle of his rifle. The Postman knows why.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm not a Holnist. The Lead Bandit pokes again. Harder. The Postman opens his shirt, reveals his bare left shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Okay? They just stare at him, none saying a word. Creepy.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm headed for a town called St. Rose. Somewhere west of Portland. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEAD BANDIT
dialogues.text: Portland's under twenty feet of water.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Well, I heard different.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD BANDIT
dialogues.text: You mouthin' me?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: No, it's just that it's hard to get good information. The third BANDIT, a HULKING brute, has been quiet.

dialogues.speaker: HULKING BANDIT
dialogues.text: He is mouthin' you; I say we kill him.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD BANDIT
dialogues.text: Don't be in such a rush, Martin. (back to The Postman) Now I see a pack mule over there, but I don't see no packs.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: This is all I got.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD BANDIT
dialogues.text: Oh... Kill him, Martin. The Hulking Bandit, raises his shotgun. The butt end. He's going to bludgeon The Postman to death.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (pointing) Okay! My stuff's up there! The 76 ball is twenty feet above the ground. In the gloom you can just see a hole has been punched through the side

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: What do you got in there? The Lead Bandit swats Bandit #20 upside the head.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD BANDIT
dialogues.text: Shut up. (to Postman) What do you got in there? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Dried peas. Beef jerky. Cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: ALL THREE BANDITS
dialogues.text: Cigarettes!

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Sure. There's the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: Maybe he's got it booby-trapped. The Lead Bandit is about to smack Bandit #20 again -- the he sees the logic out of it. The Postman shakes his head, but isn't that convincing.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD BANDIT
dialogues.text: You go up and get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladder set against the bent pole. Prodded by a shotgun, The Postman climbs, disappears through the hole and into the tilting 76 ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of The Postman's earthly possessions. Trick is, how to save them and his life at the same time. He spies an old wrench: remnant of an attempt to remove the rusty bolts holding the ball in place. An idea begins to take shape.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD BANDIT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just you start tossing those cigarettes down!

dialogues.speaker: BANDITS
dialogues.text: There's no answer. The Bandits eye each other nervously.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: Maybe he fell asleep. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BALL
dialogues.text: The Postman grabs the wrench, starts working one of the last two rusted bolts. As it starts to give...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: It's going to take a second. I got my stuff bolted in.

dialogues.speaker: BANDITS
dialogues.text: The Lead Bandit takes a cautious step back.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD BANDIT
dialogues.text: Put some buckshot through it, Martin. Just to hurry him up.

dialogues.speaker: HULKING BANDIT
dialogues.text: I only got three shells left.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD BANDIT
dialogues.text: So use his gun. The Hulking Bandit picks up the carbine and aims. CLICK. It isn't loaded. The Hulking Bandit tosses the gun aside, pulls a knife from his boot. Grimly, he begins to climb.

dialogues.speaker: BALL
dialogues.text: Cramped, The Postman's busy at the base of the ball, trying to unscrew the last remaining bolt. It won't budge.

dialogues.speaker: LADDER
dialogues.text: The Hulking Bandit has only a few more rungs to go.

dialogues.speaker: BALL
dialogues.text: No good. Time's up. The Postman starts rocking the pole.

dialogues.speaker: LADDER
dialogues.text: The Hulking Bandit has reached the opening -- feels the rocking motion. Hangs on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BALL
dialogues.text: Knife in hand, the Hulking Bandit looks inside. At that instant, The Postman rocks the pole one more time. The rusty bolt is not enough to keep the ball's full weight i place. It pops. The ball is frozen for an instant before going with the pole's tilt.

dialogues.speaker: LADDER
dialogues.text: The 76 ball drops off the pole, rolling over the Hulking Bandit's back and down the ladder's incline. The other Bandits dive clear as the 76 ball hurtles past.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: whips head over heels as the ball speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The 76 ball launches off a dirt berm, but soon comes to a stop as it slams into an old utility pole and bursts apart. Fighting the vertigo, The Postman staggers to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Bill! Bill bolts from the station as the Lead Bandit raises the RIFLE and FIRES at The Postman. Losing balance, The Postman lands on his butt just before a bullet splinters the utility pole above his head. Wobbly, he tries to gather his packs. The Bandits charge, quickly closing the ground, but Bill is there first. Holding as much as he can, The Postman heaves himself ove Bill's back. As the mule gallops away, the Lead Bandit aims the rifle. He's got The Postman in his sights. He's about to fire when -- Bandit #20 stands up INTO the SHOT. He's got a fistful of cigarettes in each hand and he's laughing like a hyena!

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: We're rich!  10 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman sits on a rock, holding Bill's halter so the mule must face him. They are in the midst of an argument.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: It's true, we haven't done this in a while, but it's like riding a bicycle. Now, open your mouth. The Postman pries his mouth open. Taking a toothbrush, he tends to Bill's teeth, then gives him an appraising look. BILL BRAYS.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I know the rule. It's my rule! Avoid civilization at all costs. But we gotta eat, don't we? (as BILL BRAYS again) What are you so worried about, Bill? All you gotta do is stand there. I'm the one with all the lines. The Postman leads the mule down the hill toward the town far below. Making his case all the while -- even as BILL BRAYS in protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patch of mud. In the center of the square fifty townspeople stand before a plank stage where The Postman wraps up a performance of MacBeth. He plays it with a mis-remembered gusto the people enjoy. Children especially are enamored. A heavily-muscled man, WOODY, lingers on the fringe of the crowd -- watching The Postma with inscrutable intensity.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: They said, 'Fear not, MacBeth, ‘til Birnam Wood comes to Dunsinane' ! He looks off stage for someone, but no one appears.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I said, Birnam Wood comes to Dunsinane! Bill trots on-stage. Covered with twigs, BILL is Birnam Wood. He BRAYS lustily. The audience laughs in delight. The children clap. Only Woody seems unaffected. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman grabs two wooden swords -- he knows it's goin well.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Arm, arm yourselves! If the witch's words are true, there'll be no running or hiding here! Shaking off the twigs, Bill takes one of the swords in hi mouth. The two of them dash back and forth pretending to fight off an imaginary attack. Finally, The Postman looks out at the audience, remembers the words the best he can.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and the day after that. Out brief candle! Life's but a walking shadow, a poor player that struts his hour upon the stage and is heard no more. It's a tale told by a moron. Full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. (waves sword) But blow, wind! Come wrack! At least we'll die with the harness off our back! The audience erupts in applause. But Woody stands still as stone. The Postman takes a bow. Even Bill does a cross-legged dip. Knowing when to quit, he steps off the stage to many hearty handshakes. Woody watches his every move. MRS. THOMPSON, one of the town's leaders, steps up. She's accompanied by crotchety old CURMUDGEON LARRY.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. THOMPSON
dialogues.text: The children have never heard Shakespeare before.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (grinning) They still haven't. The Curmudgeon is still clapping.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. You're very nice.

dialogues.speaker: CURMUDGEON LARRY
dialogues.text: I'm clapping because you stink. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand how it works.

dialogues.speaker: CURMUDGEON LARRY
dialogues.text: When I was young, I tried to be an actor. I was awful. But now I won't die thinking I was the worst one.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm glad I could help.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Larry, stop it. (to The Postman) You were very good.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Good enough to get something to eat? Before she can answer, a SENTRY cries...

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Holnists! Holnists are coming! All eyes look down the road leading into town. A raiding party of Holnist Cavalry are on their way in. Mrs. Thompson sees The Postman's concern.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. THOMPSON
dialogues.text: It's okay. We give them food and supplies. All the towns do.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: They hardly kill anyone lately. Just take a woman sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Well, I'd just as soon not give them anything of mine. Let's find the back door, Bill. The Postman gathers his stuff, slings packs onto Bill. The forty Holnists in orange and black uniforms ride in. They're armed with mostly pistols and rifles. Some carry bows, knives, spear guns and swords. On their bare shoulders, branded into the flesh!-- the number "8." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Out front, always leading by example is, GENERAL BETHLEHEM. Tough, smart, merciless with style. Commander of the United Clans of Holn. Nothing escapes his eye. A little behind him is the mysteriously silent Colonel Getty, second in command. The Postman, finished packing, begins to move from building to building!-- careful not to attract any attention.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing there? The Postman freezes, turns, is relieved to find Bethlehem's not talking to him at all. The General looks down from his horse at children playing an impromptu game of "Birnam Wood." The children stop, stare at their feet. Bethlehem affects a "kindly" smile to accompany his gentler tone.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: I said, what are you doing? Meantime, The Postman continues his surreptitious escape. The MAYOR hurries forward to greet Bethlehem.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: It's just a game, General Bethlehem. Something they saw in a play. No harm in it.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: A play? (to kids) Show me. It's all right, children, show me. One BRAVE BOY finds his voice, barely.

dialogues.speaker: BRAVE BOY
dialogues.text: Arm, arm yourselves! No running from the witches!

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (surprised) Shakespeare, is it? Well, I'm sorry I missed it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: You should know, sir, we haven't nearly stocked the game we thought we would.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Really? But you had time for a play? Head down, The Postman makes for "the back way." But it's guarded by three daunting Holnist soldiers. No getting by them. The Postman does a quick 180, goes back the way he came. Bethlehem looks at the frightened townsfolk.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: I'm taking three conscripts from each town. They will have the honor of serving in the Holnist Army until such time as I see fit. (to Mayor) Three men. You suppose you could do that? The Mayor nods in acquiescence. Bethlehem looks to a Holnist officer. The officer, IDAHO, steps up and addresses the town.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: All men between 15 and 50 and of suitable ethnic foundation are required to show themselves now. The Holnist soldiers fan out, prodding any likely or unwilling candidates forward. The Postman is now walking behind Bethlehem. Some of the Townspeople cast him a furtive glance as he makes his way toward the open courtyard and, ultimately, the gate out o town. Three conscripts are hustled before Bethlehem. He looks over the first -- Woody. Smells him. Not much of a decision here.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Acceptable.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Acceptable, Captain! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The second -- a thin teenager. Bethlehem feels his arm, turns his head from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You'll need to put some meat on, but I like an impressionable mind. Acceptable. The third -- an innocuous man. Or so we think. Bethlehem stares hard at his olive skin, traces a finger over the bump on the man's nose.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Mongoloid. Unacceptable. Soldiers shove the man back into the crowd. The Brave Boy that was playing Birnam Wood allows himself a tiny smile when he sees that The Postman might make it.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: I want pure blood. Someone like... Bethlehem notes the Boy, turns to see the object of his attention, and spots The Postman leaving out the front gate.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: That man. Idaho and another soldier are on it. The Postman tries to back away as the two dismount and come toward him.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You don't understand... But Idaho and the soldier aren't programmed for explanations!-- they grab him.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: You were required to show yourself.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: But, I'm not with these people. I'm just passing through. I -- Idaho silences him with a rifle butt to the head. Everything falls OUT OF FOCUS

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Take the mule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spread out in the valley is General Bethlehem's Holnist Expeditionary Force. A five hundred-man army enjoying all the comforts a bivouac can offer. 19 head-shaved CONSCRIPTS, including Woody and The Postman, are held in a cramped, barbed wired pen. They watch as three more are shoved inside. One of them is Bandit #20. He and The Postman come face to face, recognize each other.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (astonished) Hi? The Postman steps toward him, Bandit #20 backs off quickly.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: Well... I mean, we know each other, kind of...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Kind of.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: (looking around) Wow!

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: So what did you guys do with my cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: We traded them for a woman.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Wonderful. What happened to your partners?

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: They traded me to the Holnists.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ten hut! General Bethlehem approaches on horseback. Colonel Getty follows behind. Bethlehem looks his new recruits over. Dismounting, he enters the pen and walks among them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Welcome, gentlemen, to your new life. You have been born again as soldiers in the army of the United Clans of Holn. The strong have been sapped by the whimpering propaganda of the weak. Men, strong men, have been denied their destiny. You men have been saved from that fate. Redemption is within your grasp. He starts down the line, looking the men over. He stops in front of a GANGLY RECRUIT. The Postman is alongside.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You. What did you do before you were given this opportunity?

dialogues.speaker: GANGLY RECRUIT
dialogues.text: I had a shovel. I digged holes. Bethlehem regards him benevolently.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You digged holes... Well, now you're going to fill them. (turns to Postman) And you?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Is there any question in anyone's mind that I was talking to you? Yes, you. You look like a dangerous man. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm just a performer. Shakespeare. Stuff like that.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Shakespeare?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: He was a writer. He --

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: I know who Shakespeare was... ‘Cry "Havoc!" and let slip the dogs of war.' (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bethlehem says the lines boldly, encourages his men to clap for him. He looks at The Postman expectantly. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I, um, you want a line? Bethlehem nods. The Postman thinks a moment...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: ‘To be or not to be: That is the question.’ Bethlehem looks at his men as if to say, "Is this all thi guy's got?" Bethlehem eyes The Postman; he wants a contest.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: ‘We few, we happy few, we band of brothers.' The Holnists clap, they know their General can best this guy.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (gaining confidence) ‘Now is the winter of our discontent made glorious summer by this son of York.' Bethlehem claps The Postman on the back.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You're pretty good. You're also a fighter. I see it in your eyes. The Postman doesn't answer. Hesitant, he doesn't want to get into any more trouble than he's already in.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Don't you agree? Come on, a man's got to speak his mind. Bethlehem sounds sincere. He seems like a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't mean any disrespect, sir, but you'd be better off just letting me go. A fighter is about the last thing I am. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman doubles over as Bethlehem hooks a fist into his gut. Bethlehem clubs him in the head, dropping him to his knees, then digs a boot into his side. The Postman goes down.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Don't you think I should be the judge of that, soldier? The Postman gasps to catch his breath.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Get up. I said, get up. The Postman staggers to his feet. Blood trickles from his nose as he stares across at Bethlehem.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Put up your fists.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You'd win. Bethlehem looks to Getty. CLICK. Getty shoves a PISTOL is into The Postman's ear. The Postman reluctantly raises his fists. Bethlehem gives him a satisfied nod.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Now fight. The Postman takes a tentative step forward. Bethlehem drives him back with a flurry of blows. The Postman is dazed, nearly out on his feet. Bethlehem holds him up.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You're right. You're not a fighter. But you will be. I'm giving you a chance at a life that means something. A life worth living. That said, Bethlehem delivers one last blow to The Postman's face. Everything goes BLACK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brutal REVEILLE BLASTS the sleeping conscripts awake.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Let's move it. Everybody up and at ‘em. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman comes to. He licks his dry, blood-caked lips. A sudden movement startles him!-- it's Woody, shoving him a battered cup of water. It's like he's been keeping watch. The Postman is surprised, a little suspicious, and very grateful as he gulps the water down.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Did I win? Woody shakes his head "no.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I tried to tell him...

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: The words you said in town. About the wind blowing. And the rest... Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: "Blow, wind. Come wrack. At least we'll die with the harness off our back.’

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What's it mean?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Live free or die. Woody and The Postman scramble to fall-to with the other conscripts. Idaho surveys the ranks.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: All right, girls. We're gonna run. Twenty miles. With packs. You got three hours. Everybody makes it. Or nobody eats.

dialogues.speaker: MEAT
dialogues.text: A COOK dumps a scoop of gristly, gray meat into each mess pail as the conscripts wait in line. They fall to ravenously, too hungry to taste how bad it is. Idaho supervises. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: Eat up! You got meat tonight. The line has almost passed. Just The Postman left and Bandit #20 bringing up the rear. Idaho looks at The Postman, addresses the COOK.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell Shakespeare what kind of meat that is.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Mule. Probably Bill !-- and The Postman knows it. He stares in revulsion at the putrid meat ladled into his pail.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: A godawful animal. The sterile offspring of a horse and a donkey. Can you imagine that?! There's no room in this new world for a bastard like that. Bandit #20 holds out his pail. But the cook won't fill it.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: Uh uh. (loudly; for all) Any man last in line ain't hungry enough. You show up last, you don't eat! Bandit #20 steps away in disbelief. Not knowing what else to do, he sits down beside The Postman, the only man with food who isn't eating.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: I'll die before I'm last in line again.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: That's what they're hoping for. He holds his pail out to Bandit #20.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: Serious? This isn't bad. Lost in despair, The Postman stares out at the skewed palette.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: These were supposed to be the best years of my life.  14 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conscripts stand at attention under the guard of Idah and two other soldiers. To their right is a dead oak tree. Behind them, three rows of folding chairs. Two figures approach. Bethlehem and Getty. Getty carries a sheathed sword. Bethlehem surveys the troops!-- taking no more notice of The Postman than anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: The laws of eight, gentlemen. That is the legacy handed down to us by Nathan Holn. At the mention of this name, the RECRUITS shout as one.

dialogues.speaker: RECRUITS
dialogues.text: God rest his soul!

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (low) May he burn in hell. Getty looks over at him. He heard him. The Postman swallows hard. Getty stares hard. Then he turns away. He's not going to bust him on it.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: These are the laws that we live by. The eight is our symbol. Each man will bear it with pride. Bethlehem nods at Idaho who pushes up his own sleeve to reveal the branded 8.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Only then will you be part of the clan. Sit down, gentlemen. The men move to sit in one of the three rows. Only then does it become apparent that there are 18 men and only 17 chairs. One SLOW RECRUIT is left standing. It doesn't take him long to realize that he's in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Law One. You will obey orders without question. (to Slow Recruit) I told you to sit.

dialogues.speaker: SLOW RECRUIT
dialogues.text: (scared) There weren't enough chairs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: I didn't specify chairs. You could've sat down on the ground. The Slow Recruit moves to do so.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You disobeyed a direct order. You broke Law One. Idaho and another soldier step up beside the Slow Recruit

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Law Two. Punishment shall be swift. They hustle the Recruit to the tree. Idaho unslings a coil of rope, throws it over a tree limb. They quickly slip a loop over the Slow Recruit's ankles and haul him upside down into the air.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Law Three: Mercy is for the weak. Four: Terror will defeat reason. Five: Your allegiance is to the clan. Six: Justice can be dictated. Law Seven. Any clansman may challenge for leadership of the clan. Does any man here wish to challenge me? There are no takers.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: On your feet! The conscripts stand like jackknives snapping open. Without a word, without a look -- Bethlehem reaches out and draws a sword from a sheath that Getty holds. Bethlehem steps to the Slow Recruit -- who slowly twists around.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Law Eight: There is only one penalty: Death. Bethlehem raises the sword.

dialogues.speaker: SLOW RECRUIT
dialogues.text: Please, I'm begging you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: As the sword finds its mark. Bethlehem looks at him, but addresses all.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You will get out of this army what you put into it. Work and you'll be fed. Fight and you'll be respected. Die and you'll be remembered. It's up to you. Bethlehem turns and walks away. Getty following behind. The Postman watches as they go. Idaho steps up to him.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: You thinking of challenging for leadership of the clan?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: No, sir. I'ma follower not a leader.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: You see Colonel Getty? Always following the General? He's the only man who ever challenged. Fight lasted six seconds, but the General didn't kill him. He cut off his tongue and he cut off his balls and old Getty's been following him like a dog ever since. The Postman looks back to see Bethlehem and Getty disappear into the gloom. Idaho grins, likes how this affects a new man. The Postman moves on. Idaho stops Woody as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: The General don't see it, but I say you got some nigger in you. Woody clenches his jaw, but wisely doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain as the army moves. Boots suck at the mud. War wagons heave out of ruts. A monster gun is mounted on an old John Deere semi, pulled by a team of ten horses. The conscripts fill the middle ranks, each bearing a heavy pack. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Marching beside Woody, The Postman stares blankly ahead. The cry to halt. The conscripts unsling their packs, catch their breath. Idaho pulls The Postman out of line.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: The General would like a word with you, Shakespeare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem stands before a painter's easel, palette in hand. He's got a mirror set up so he can see his reflection. He's doing a self-portrait in the tradition of the great Dutch Masters -- but it's a dismal failure. He continues painting even as Idaho leads The Postman in. Idaho salutes, steps back. For a moment, The Postman doesn't quite know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (re: the book and binoculars on the table) They're yours. A solitary man, aren't you? Binoculars. To watch life from a distance. And Shakespeare. To read about it instead of living it. Bethlehem wants an answer. The Postman clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: No offense, General, but you seem to have read some Shakespeare yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: If he wishes to rise above mere thuggery, a military commandeer must be classically educated. Philosophy, history. Even a sense of the dramatic. (a beat) Do you know what I did before the war? Do you think I was in the army? I sold copying machines. I was a salesman. The talent to lead men and devise and execute a battle plan were locked away inside me. (CONTINUED)
16 He picks up Finding A Way to Win by Nathan Holn. A 20- year-old self-help book.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: If Nathan Holn hadn't come along, I'd still be selling copying machines. Can you imagine the wasted life? Can you imagine the magnitude of it? But war... War gives men like me a chance. He turns to a dog-eared page in the book.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Here... 'The prize is often left unclaimed. Have the courage to grasp it. For fortune always favors the bold.' (moved) It always inspires me. (beat) I have a design for the future. master plan. I'll need able officers to carry it out. You have the intelligence. If your heart matches, you'll go far. (a beat) We'll talk more in the weeks to come. Dismissed. The Postman leaves. Idaho stands at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Issue the binoculars to a scout.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: And the book, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Burn it. Idaho leaves. Bethlehem goes back to his painting. He considers himself in the mirror. After a long stare-down, he shouts:

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Quit moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 The Postman rejoins the conscripts. Bandit #20 slides over. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: What happened? Troubled, The Postman doesn't answer. He heads for a corner where Woody stands alone. Relentless, Bandit #20 follows.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: Did he say anything about me?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: No. They reach the quiet corner; it's just the three of them.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: We got to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Escaping. (low) You ever hear of St. Rose? It's on the coast. They say it's a paradise. They've even got electric lights. Bandit #20 looks scared, Woody unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: We can't.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Between the three of us, we could --

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: No, no. I can't. I like it here. I like being a part of something. The Postman can't believe what Bandit #20 just said. Bandit #20 turns, hurries away. The Postman looks to Woody who doesn't tip his hand eithe way. He moves away as well.  18 19 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conscripts break camp. Hot work. Glistening with sweat, The Postman stops to stretch. Across the way, he sees Bandit #20 talking to Getty. Getty glances at The Postman who returns to work, watches under his eyebrows a Idaho joins the group. There's trouble brewing here. Worried, The Postman looks to Woody, who watches the exchange as well. He is, as usual, inscrutable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river is swollen and swift from the spring thaw. Marching along the east ridge above it, the army is given the order to halt. The Postman looks ahead to where Idaho confers with Bethlehem. Something's wrong. They look to where: Two carbine-toting soldiers stand alertly at guard by a thicket across the river. A rotten wood and rope bridge spans the space between the ridges. Idaho rides to the conscripts:

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: One of you dogs has earned himself a treat. Over there. Idaho points to the thicket as he proceeds down the line.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: Those men hunted themselves a lion this morning. Must've been a zoo around here before the war. Anyhow, they shot him and he crawled into that thicket. A third man went in after him. We don't know if he's dead or alive. I need a volunteer. Someone's gotta go in and get our boy out. No volunteers, except the zealot Bandit #20.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: I'll go. Idaho ignores him, stops in front of Woody.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: I guess size ain't a measure of courage, is it? Shakespeare! The fix is in. The Postman steps out of line. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Idaho's about to hand The Postman a carbine when --

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Captain. Bethlehem nods to Getty. Getty takes a hunting knife from a belt-sheath and tosses it, blade first, into the ground between The Postman's feet.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Come out alive and you got yourself a lion steak. Hefting the knife, The Postman stares at the west ridge.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: (winks ) Maybe you'll find your St. Rose up there. The Postman looks to Bandit #20 who stares back defiantly

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for, Christmas? Bandit #20 can't contain his giggling, so Idaho backhands the sound out of him -- then looks back to The Postman. Grim The Postman starts forward, looks from the rotten bridge to the water and back again as he moves. All eyes on him as he starts across...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman steps lightly. Far below, the river rages. A knotty plank starts to crack underfoot. Scooting off it, he takes a last look around. Continues across to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers greet him -- unholy smiles on their ugly mugs. They point him ahead, prod him forward toward a trail of wet blood which leads deeper into the thicket. Stooping, The Postman enters. The soldiers split off and track along with him on either side of the thicket.  22 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thorns catch and tear at his clothes as The Postman pushe his way through. He freezes. Ahead, sprawled and twisted, the mauled, bloody corpse of a Holnist soldier.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why are you stopping?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I found him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He alive? Clearly he is not.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bring him out. The Postman heaves the corpse onto his back. Rising, steadying himself, he looks back over his shoulders at a GUTTURAL GROWL. He hurries forward.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY
dialogues.text: Everyone stares across the river, straining to see as The Postman emerges with the corpse on his back.

dialogues.speaker: ON BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The Postman starts across, hampered by his burden. He pauses, at his feet, the cracked, knotty plank.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: (across river) Hurry up! You still got a lion to bag! The Postman decides, deliberately steps on the PLANK. CRACK. The Postman and the corpse drop thirty feet down, disappear in the river below. The corpse surfaces first, floats in the water. Then The Postman. Farther down the river. Swimming downstream with powerful strokes. Between his efforts and the current, he's being quickly swept away from the Holnists. As Bethlehem's eyes narrow in fury. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A RIFLE BARKS a SHELL BACK after The Postman, but he disappears around a bend in the river. Bethlehem signals to two soldiers. They start running along the east ridge toward the riverbend. Two more start across the bridge to the west -- moving with military precision. Bethlehem wheels toward the conscripts, points out Woody.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: In the water. Come back without him and you and another man will die in his place. Woody dives in the water. Bethlehem looks to Idaho who dives in as well. Conscripts buzz with nervous excitement.

dialogues.speaker: CONSCRIPTS
dialogues.text: Go! Gol

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: (caught up) I'll get him, sir. He takes off running across the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fallen tree spans the river. As The Postman is swept beneath, he reaches up and catches hold. Pulling himself out of the water, he scrambles for the west shore. He disappears into the woods as two soldiers appear. They catch hold of the tree, look to the west banking, se footprints in the mud where The Postman pulled himself out. They start after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clothes in tatters, his lungs ready to burst, The Postman stops. He takes cover as the two soldiers run past. Breathing hard, The Postman steps out, starts across the clearing. He's halfway when Bandit #20 steps out from the trees. They look at each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Just let me go. I don't want to be part of your army. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bandit #20 hesitates for a moment, then breaks into a grin.

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: My army. I like the sound of that. The Postman gestures with his knife.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Don't --

dialogues.speaker: BANDIT
dialogues.text: I_got him! Over -- The Postman lunges, digs into Bandit #20's gut. He blinks in surprise, then sags to the ground. The Postman takes a step back. A shadow falls over him. It's Woody. Staring down at The Postman. They can hear others approaching from the river.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: They sent me to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Come with me. At that moment, Idaho and the second soldier come into th clearing. Idaho grins, relaxes his grip on his gun when he sees the mismatch between Woody and The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: Good, boy. Get him.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: It's you or me.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: Finish it. Woody circles The Postman, until he's facing Idaho and th soldier. Woody takes a long look at The Postman, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: No harness on my back. As The Postman realizes what he's doing, Woody flips his knife through the air and into the soldier's throat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Woody rushes him, Idaho raises his GUN. Idaho pumps TWO ROUNDS into Woody, but the big man keeps coming. The THIRD ROUND finds his heart, puts Woody down. Dead. But not before he lands on top of Idaho. As Idaho struggles to get out from under Woody's massive frame, The Postman heads for the trees. Covered in Woody's blood, Idaho FIRES a ROUND as The Postman disappears into the woods. Idaho starts after him.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: Tracking. He sees a dribble of fresh blood. He touches it with his fingers and smiles. He cocks his head at MOVEMENT to his left. Smiling, hefting his pistol, Idaho moves in. More SHUFFLING. Just ahead. He's got him now.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: You want your St. Rose? There's a RUSTLE of BRUSH just before a ROAR splits the air. Idaho doesn't even have time to scream as the LION pounces down on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman, lungs heaving, stops his climb long enough t take stock of the Army waiting on the distant river edge. Strength ebbing, he heaves himself up and continues climbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chilling RAIN drills down, washing across an old forest road. Covered with undergrowth and dotted with saplings, nothing's been down here in years. Blue-lipped and shivering, his clothes torn and soaked, The Postman trudges along. He tries to rub some warmth back into his numbed limbs, but a coughing spell wracks his body. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He trudges forward, shoes heavy with freezing mud. He's made his escape, but he won't last the night if he doesn' find some shelter. An unnatural shape ahead, just off the road. Square. He cautiously pulls back a few branches. An old, rusted Jeep with faded U.S. government markings. Its hood buried under the dirt of an old mud slide. The Postman stoops to look through the passenger side window, comes face-to-face with death. A skeleton sits inside, the skull grinning against the glass facing The Postman. But The Postman doesn't jump back. He just stares. The two heads meet halfway as The Postman's face is reflected on the glass, superimposed over the skull. A hypothermic shiver wracks his body. The Postman tries the door, but it won't budge. The other side of the Jeep is buried. But seeing that the windshield is partly smashed, he clears away the debris, peels back the spider webbed safety glass and climbs inside.

dialogues.speaker: JEEP
dialogues.text: Pulling the glass back down, he looks almost shyly at the skeleton, like two kids about to "park" for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Hey. How ya doin'? The back of the Jeep is filled with bags marked U.S. Mail The Postman picks up a hat off the console. Oddly respectful, he runs a finger along the band over the "Horse & Rider" emblem. The Postman reaches, touches the embroidered American fla patch on the skeleton's jacket shoulder. Another shiver. A moment later, The Postman is pulling the nice dry jacke off the skeleton and shoving his own arms inside. A sloshing sound. He pats down the jacket. Finds a liquor. He gives the skeleton a "you shouldn't have" look. But the cap won't budge. He twists, pries, bangs the neck of the steering wheel. At last it gives. He takes a long, hard swallow. The warming fire streams down his throat. The Postman grabs a random letter, reads it aloud. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: ‘Jerry Ball, Pine View.' He starts to open it, looks at the skeleton and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: So, arrest me. (reading) Here's a piece of good news. Jerry's decided to go to school to get his contractor's license. Tossing it aside, he takes a drink, opens another. The words are in crayon -- a child's scrawl.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (smiles to skeleton) Little Jimmy wants his grandpa to know he lost a tooth. The Postman turns the envelope over in his palm. A tiny tooth falls out. The Postman considers it. This suddenly isn't so amusing. He puts it back in the envelope. Shoving mail sacks aside, he climbs in the back. Burrowing in, he pulls the sacks back, covering himself with a blanket of mail. Getting warmer already, he regards the skeleton a beat as the RAIN DRUMS ON the ROOF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing the blue uniform, The Postman looks down at the fresh grave, realizes a eulogy is in order. He takes off the hat, holds it over his chest for a heartfelt moment o silence.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks for being there for me. (vaising the flask) Here's to you. I consider my taxes very well spent. He swallows the last few drops, then sets the flask down as a headstone. What now?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: All dressed up. Nowhere to go.  28 29 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hair growing back nicely, The Postman has reached the proverbial fork in the road. He considers his two options: "Pine View -- 32 miles." Or "Ridgemont -- 220 miles." He looks the two roads over, thinks.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Well, that's easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town is protected by a tall, long palisade. Like Ft. Apache. All is dark as The Postman approaches.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Greetings, Pine View, Oregon! TWO SENTRIES appears from the gate house. They aim arrows.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Just head back the way you came. Pine View ain't buying, ain't listening and don't give charity. A moment of truth is here. Finally, with authority:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Civilian, I'm on official business. I demand entry into the town of Pine View.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm through talking to you, buddy boy! Now get somebody with authority to open this gate! More silhouettes appear on the palisade. One is SHERIFF BRISCOE, a big, no-nonsense man.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: I'm Sheriff Briscoe. Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm a representative of the United States Government -- An uproar. He makes himself heard above it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Authorized by order 417 of the restored Congress to reestablish a communication route to Idaho and lower Oregon. Now open that damn gate!

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: What does that mean in English?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm your postman! There's a silent hush.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: (to someone on wall) Hand me your gun.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Understand that tampering with or obstructing the mail is a federal offense. Furthermore, the Bolin Act requires you to provide all mail carriers with sanctuary and nourishment. (starting forward) Now open that damn gate!

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: You got three seconds to get your ass outta here.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Is Jerry the contractor here? Briscoe pumps his shotgun, aims it at The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Wait! I'm going to get something out of my bag. The Postman dumps the pack over, frantically shuffles through the letters.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: One!

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Paul Davis! 124 Vernon Street!

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Never heard of him. Two! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Lois Kent! 14 Weymoth Lane!

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Three! He fumbles for the last letter. Briscoe takes aim.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Irene March! 478 River Road! There's an absolute stunned silence. Like a switch was thrown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd parts as everyone turns to look back at IRENE MARCH. Mrs. March, in her late 50s, is blind, her eyes clouded by cataracts. In disbelief...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: Did he say my name? The sense of hope is palpable as the gates are swung back Two TOWNIES hurry Mrs. March out to meet The Postman. They're followed by a throng. As he sees she's blind...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, no... Too late now. They stop Mrs. March in front of him. She stares off just to his left, a little afraid.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: I'm Irene March.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) I have a letter for you. He presses it into her hands, but she won't take it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: Would you read it?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's personal.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: Please. Someone has to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman has little choice. As he opens the envelope...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: We're delivering the old stock piles, but I'll accept all new correspondence as well.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNIE
dialogues.text: Just read it, will ya? Excited, the people move closer. Someone holds up a torch and The Postman starts.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: ‘Dear Irene. Sorry I haven't written. Everything's so crazy. The strange weather. The food shortages. That farmer Nathan Holn causing all that trouble. It's hard to understand. David's home from the Army. The war was over before he even got there. Thank God for that. He's still my baby no matter how big he gets. We're going to miss you for Christmas, but maybe next year. All our love. Donna. Mrs. March reaches out a trembling hand to take the letter.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: My sister in Denver. Fifteen years ago. Thank you. The populace erupts with excitement. Mrs. March takes The Postman's hand, clasps it tightly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: You're a Godsend. A savior. The Postman pulls his hand back, rejects the title.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: No. I'm just... a postman. An almost awesome silence. Too much for The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I've been on the road a while. I could use a little something to eat -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, absolutely... Is there anything else? The townspeople welcome him with cheers. The Postman raises a silencing hand. As they quiet...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, there is! If there are dogs in this town, you have to leash them while I'm here! Only The Postman laughs. No one else reacts. Briscoe watches dubiously from the wall as the people surround Th Postman and sweep him through the gates and into town. One couple watches The Postman closely as he makes his wa into town. She is ABBY -- a sweet-faced, pretty woman. Her husband, MICHAEL, is a decent-looking sort, tall and strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A freestanding tub has been set up, water "bucketed" in. The Postman luxuriates in his first hot bath in years and sings a familiar tune to himself.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: ‘Stop. Oh, yes, wait a minute, Mr. Postman. Waaa-ait, Mr. Postman...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FORD crosses the parking lot of an abandoned motel. He's a black kid, maybe 16, too young to remember any other life but this. He carries The Postman's uniform on a hanger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks up at a KNOCK. Ford steps in. Like most kids, he needs a hero. Holding up the uniform, he just found one.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: (beaming) Cleaned and pressed, sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Didn't somebody say something about dinner?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm supposed to take you to Foster's. (extending a hand) My name's Ford. Ford Lincoln Mercury. The Postman just nods, hoisting himself out of the tub an hurriedly wrapping a towel around himself.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Used to be John Stevens, but I changed it on account of I want to drive cars. Hoping to impress, Ford reaches into a pocket, pulls out worn, creased flyer for a "Ford Lincoln Mercury" dealership. Ford finds The Postman just staring at him, waiting for the uniform he's still got in his hand. Embarrassed, Ford quickly hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford leads the way as they leave the motel behind. The Postman looks good in his uniform. They cross a parking lot where five partly-stripped cars have been sitting for years. There's a potted plant outside the driver's door of one.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I live in that car. A 2003 Pontiac Sinatra. With a nine- banger and a Q-eight.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: V-eight. Eight cylinders. That means an eight-banger.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: (in awe of him) Were they fast?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: A buck seventy-five on a strip. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: A buck seventy-five? I thought maybe I could fix some of them up. It's nothing compared to what you do. This is the last thing he expected to hear out of this kid's mouth. A moment, then...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: The important thing to remember about cars is, you can't eat ‘em. Ahead, people are gathered inside an old Foster's Freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The townspeople fill the booths, line the walls. They talk excitedly amongst themselves, break into spontaneous applause as Ford and The Postman enter. The Postman is surprised, uncomfortable at this display. But then he sees that a banquet has been laid out on the counter. The centerpiece is a huge vat of steaming stew. The PEOPLE clear a path for him.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Tell us about the government!

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, tell us everything! Startled, The Postman doesn't quite know what to say. They seat him at a table -- but the food looks miles away

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Is there a President?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You know, I'm pretty hungry. But these people won't be denied. Finally... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: His name is, uh... Richard Starkey. From Maine. He has a saying. 'Things are getting better, getting better all the time.' There's warm applause at that. Several people try the expression out on each other.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: He a Democrat or a Republican?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Parties are over with. The individual is what counts. You vote for the best man. Ellen sets a steaming bowl of stew in front of The Postman. Famished, he digs in.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What about Europe? Any word? The Postman tries to speak through a mouthful of food.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Lady Di's in charge. Sixty years old and she still kicks ass.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Is Nathan Holn still alive?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (smiles at irony) He died. Skin cancer. That's sure good news to everyone. But...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: And the Holnists? They're still out there. What's the government going to do about them? The Postman looks at the desperate faces -- he'd rather get back to his meal -- but this may be the most importan question of all. He doesn't want to lie.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: The government's just getting started. You're on your own for at least eighteen months. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What about the Marines Corp? A clamor of Holnist questions.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Be quiet, everyone! Can't we just let this man eat? The people nod and The Postman finally gets to eat. He catches sight of Briscoe watching him from the door. After a moment, Briscoe leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A band plays an odd array of instruments. There's dancing. The Postman sits behind four empty bowls. People watch him eat like it was a religious experience. He pushes back the fifth bowl.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Never thought I'd hear myself say this, but I can't eat anymore. He's cut off by the sight of a silent, little boy. The kid's looking up, staring intently at something.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What? The boy just stares.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: hi (re: the cap) This? The boy nods. The Postman shakes his head and smiles to himself. He takes off the cap, sets it on the kid's head.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Almost fits. The boy's eyes go wide with wonder. His stock's gone up 1000%. Before he can rush off to impress his friends, ELLEN -- his mother -- steps over and gently chides him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That's not a toy, honey. That's very important. Give it back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The boy carefully removes the cap, hands it back to The Postman. Ellen smiles gratefully and gently guides her son away. The Postman shrugs, turns to find Abby, the pretty woman we saw at the Pine View gates. She smiles at The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Would you like to dance?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't know if I can, I think I'm still on duty. He laughs. Abby says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: It's been a long time. Abby holds out her hand like a promise.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: All you got to do is hold on.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Abby and The Postman dance. She keeps looking him over.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: How tall are you?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: About six feet.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Are you smart?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Smarter than some I guess. Why?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Just wondering. Did you ever have the bad mumps? The Postman smiles. She's odd, but beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Never had the bad mumps. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Have you ever had herpes or syphilis or anything like that? He shakes his head "no." They continue to dance.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: So as far as you know, you have good semen?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Is that a trick question?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I don't mean to be nosy. I'm only asking because I want you to make me pregnant. Stunned, The Postman stops dancing. Abby takes this moment to grab Michael.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (to himself) It's got to be the uniform. Abby takes Michael's arm, introduces him proudly.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: This is my husband. Michael. Michael smiles, shakes hands with a grave-digger's grip. The Postman doesn't know what to think.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: We've been trying to have a baby for three years. We can't on account of Michael had the bad mumps when he was twelve. So we need a body father. We could ask aman here, but it could cause trouble. I've seen it happen. Things go okay until the woman starts to show. Then it can be bad. But you'll only be around once in awhile with the mail. The Postman just stares at them. Abby looks to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: He hasn't said ‘no’. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (undaunted) What do you say, mister? You'd be doing us a favor.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'll have to think about it. The Postman excuses himself with a nod and turns away, shaking his head at the strangeness of this new world. But no rest for the wicked, as soon as he's free from Abb and Michael, he's running smack into another group of well-wishing TOWNIES. Mrs. March is among them. She's holding an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. March wants to give you something. (to Mrs. March) He's right here, Irene.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: (re: letter) It's to my daughter Annie. She left five years ago. She was only fifteen. The last I heard, she was living up north... The Postman swallows hard, looks from the envelope to the faces around him, to Mrs. March. She looks blindly back. How can he lie to her?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Look, Mrs. March, you should know that...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: Know what?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Know that... But she stops him, grabs for his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARCH
dialogues.text: I have a feeling about you. I know you'll do what's right. Her hand leaves his and she disappears into the crowd. She's left him with her letter and no choice at all.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I got to get out of here.  37 38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman moves through town. The streets are deserted. He's got his pack on, his mailbag. He passes a 7-11 converted to a blacksmith shop. There's a horse tethered to the railing in front of it. He grins; maybe he's going to make it out of here after all. As he starts to move toward the horse... OLD MAN (0.S. It's right around the corner. An OLD MAN sits on his porch across the street.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (freezes, startled) What is?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: What you're looking for. The Old Man winks knowingly, then heads inside. As The Postman turns the corner, he finds himself in front of th post office. An old brick building. Chiseled in the granite facing: "UNITED STATES POST OFFICE. EST. 1884."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long ago stripped, it still has a proud, official, almost holy feel. The Postman wanders in, stops to read the credo calligraphied on the wall. "Neither snow, nor rain..." He turns at a SOUND. Ford is here, leaning against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I knew you'd come here.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You did, huh? Ford nods. A sage sixteen-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: How do you get to be a postman, anyhow?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You have to be in the right place at the right time.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: How could I do it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted to drive cars.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Not anymore. That was kid's stuff. This is real. So, where's the right place?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Could be anywhere. Anytime. Only another postman can make you a postman.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Kinda like vampires, right?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Something like that. You have to be sworn in. Ford raises his right hand, palm out, ready to take the oath. It takes The Postman a moment to realize.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: The organization's kinda shaky. It might not last.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: What does?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You'd meet a lot of people who don't believe in you.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I'll set them straight.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: It's a lonely job.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I've been lonely all my life. This response strikes a chord. The Postman sees how badly Ford wants something to hold onto. He sees himself.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: So have I, Ford. So have I. The Postman looks up at the creed on the wall. Finally... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What the hell? Repeat after me.

dialogues.speaker: POSTMAN/FORD
dialogues.text: (repeating) Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: (repeating) Okay, then.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: No, no, no, I'm saying that. You just listen... By my authority you are now empowered to carry the mail. (extends a hand) Congratulations, you're a postman. They shake hands. The Postman doesn't realize, but this is the most important moment in Ford's life.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I want you to know I'd die to get a letter through. Ford's intensity takes The Postman back. But the moment is broken when...

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Johnny, why don't you run along. I need to speak to this man. Ford bristles at "Johnny," looks to The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I'll see you around.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Sure thing, Ford. Ford exits.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Johnny's real impressed with you. Whole town's real impressed with you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I take it you're not.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Smarter than you look.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: You can clear out. Or I can throw you out. Either way suits me fine.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you don't understand, Sheriff. I'm a government employee. Authorized by --

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: You're not authorized by shit. You're nothing but a drifter who found a bag of mail. And I want you out of my town.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: This is going in my report.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: These people don't need dreams, Mr. Postman. They need something real. They need help with the goddamn Holnists. Are you going to bring them that? (as The Postman doesn't answer) Didn't think so. All you cost us so far is a few bowls of soup and maybe later a few broken hearts. I aim to keep it that way. You can stay till morning. Then I don't ever want to see you again. Briscoe exits, leaves The Postman alone in the post office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman arrives home. He pushes open the door, knocking over a stack of letters that have been shoved under the door. He gathers them up, flips through them. They're written on scraps, the backs of pictures, on handkerchiefs and homemade paper. They aren't old. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They're brand new. Shaking his head, he closes the door. The Postman has no sooner done so when there's a KNOCK on the window. He looks over at a woman. She shrugs, smiles, holds up a letter. The Postman sighs; he's trapped in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STARTS ON a man with a string-tied package crossin the streets and DRIFTS TO the abandoned car where Ford lives. He's home.

dialogues.speaker: ON FORD
dialogues.text: Concentrating, Ford holds a needle and thread and a piece of cloth on which he's drawn an approximation of the post office shoulder patch. By moonlight he embroiders it in. Not exactly work you'd pay money for, but not bad either. INT. ABANDONED HOTEL - ROOM 7 - CLOSE ON STRING-TIED 4l

dialogues.speaker: PACKAGE
dialogues.text: ~from the previous scene. It's on the table with a growing stack of mail. The Postman is in bed, trying to sleep. But it's hard- coming. He laces his fingers behind his head, stares up at the moon through a hole in the wall. A KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Just leave it. There's a pause. And then, ANOTHER KNOCK.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I said leave it. The door opens. Surprise. Abby stands in the doorway, her hair held up by an old red ribbon. He sits up.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Abby.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You'll be leaving tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I guess. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 54. CONTINUED: 4l

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (enters; closes door) Everybody's up late writing letters for you to take. We're not supposed to waste candles like that, but they're so excited.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: How about you? Do you have a letter?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I don't have anybody to write to.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'll find you a pen pal. Someone with interests similar to your own. Dancing, checking for mumps. Abby laughs. The Postman is charmed.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You're funny. Hardly anyone's funny around here.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I guess no one feels much like laughing. The two of them just look at each other a moment. Abby fingers the ribbon in her hair.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Have you decided yet?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I've been thinking about it. A beat. Abby lets her shift drop to the floor, then slides under the sheets alongside him.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Sure. Why not? They lie there awkwardly for a moment. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: God, you're beautiful. Sorry, I know you'd probably like to keep things more clinical. (beat) You don't even know my name. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She shushes him, covers his mouth with her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I don't want to. He nods he understands. She stares into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It would be easier for me if you closed your eyes. The Postman closes his eyes. Abby slides her hand away from his mouth. And as they start to make love...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman wakes, reaches for the warm body that was there last night. But Abby is gone. All that's left behind is her red ribbon. Wistful, he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman exits. In uniform, his bag slung over his shoulder. He starts then stops short. Only now do we see most of the townspeople have silently assembled here. They've been waiting for him, starving for him. Ford steps up, hands him another fresh packet of letters. The Postman sees that Ford hangs on to four or five.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What about those?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: These are going to Blue Jay. About twenty miles east. I thought I could take them. The Postman scans the crowd. Looking for Abby maybe?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (absently) Okay. They're yours. Briscoe rides up, regards The Postman sternly.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: I'm your escort out of town. Some of the town's CITIZENS lead up a saddled mare. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CITIZEN
dialogues.text: We took a vote, Mr. Postman. We want you to have this horse.

dialogues.speaker: CITIZEN
dialogues.text: Now don't say no. A man on horseback can cover ten times the territory of a man on foot.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (smiles at Briscoe) I'll take it. He ties his mailbag to the saddle, swings himself up.

dialogues.speaker: CITIZEN
dialogues.text: There's a bedroll, some oats and a week's rations.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CITIZEN
dialogues.text: Where do you figure you'll go from here?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Go?... Oh yeah... I'll head west, then work my way back here in a sort of figure eight. "8." Everyone's quiet a moment. They shift uncomfortably. The Postman looks out at the crowd. They crave hope. He should probably just keep his mouth shut.
