dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Times seem hard right now. But you have to believe it's getting better. Birds are migrating again. The rains are back. The people consider him and then each other. By God, they do feel hopeful. Suddenly, Ellen, her little boy by her side, begins to sing. It's weak at first, but one-by-one the others join in. Soon the whole town is singing:

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: ‘Oh beautiful for spacious skies, for amber waves of grain. For purple mountain's majesty, above the fruited plain. America...' The Postman looks around. They sing their hearts out. The guilt is overwhelming. He digs his heels into the horse's flanks and rides out of town.  44 45 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People line the top as The Postman and Briscoe ride out. The strains of "AMERICA" still in the background.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: You got a helluva nerve, whoever you are. The Postman doesn't rise to the bait.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Is Abby around?

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: She and Michael are working the north meadow this morning. Briscoe reins up!-- he's gone as far as his duty commands

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Well, you're on your own. The Postman tips his cap and continues riding by "Pine View!- Population 132." Briscoe watches a moment, then calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Hey! Are you really who you say you are?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: If I come back with some mail, you'll know! The Postman continues. Caught in an inner turmoil, Briscoe reaches into his pocket, and pulls out a letter. He turns it over in his hands, looks off at The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: God damn it! Briscoe urges his horse forward, catches up. He hands The Postman the letter, then rides back for town. The Postman watches Briscoe. The people lining the wall. And he realizes just what effect he's had. There's nothing to do, but shrug his shoulders and ride. Strains of "AMERICA" still ECHO hauntingly OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A green and lavender sunset. In the middle of nowhere, The Postman rides, chewing a piece of jerked beef. He flips through some of the letters entrusted to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Eugene. Benning. Portland. (stops short) Boston! (resumes ) Seattle. Boise... St. Rose, Paradise on the Pacific... He considers the letter, looks around as if someone may b watching. He just begins to tear the corner, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe one thing can still be sacred. (to horse) All in all, not a bad gig, huh? The HORSE SNORTS. Smiling, The Postman shoves the envelope into his bag. As he does, he finds something else. The red ribbon. He runs it through his fingers, thinks wistfully of Abby. Then, like a knight of old representing a lady's honor, he ties it to his mailbag an rides on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby's washing clothes with a tub and washboard. Waging war on dirt. Michael leans against a tree, watches Abby at work until she notices him. She wipes the sweat from her brow, tries not to smile.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What are you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Everything. He steps over and they're in each other's arms. This is love. But as Michael kisses her, we hear a familiar alarm:

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Holnists! Holnists are coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Led by Bethlehem and Getty, the soldiers ride in. Something about the citizens disturbs Bethlehem.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: They don't usually look at me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bethlehem reins in across from the post office. Someone has hung a tattered old American flag.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Who's responsible for that?! No one answers. All heads are down now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford is sweeping up. The place looks almost presentable. He stops when he hears Bethlehem calling once more for th responsible party. Ford starts forward. Suddenly Briscoe is blocking his way.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Holnists, Johnny. You gotta stay out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I'm a postman. And I'm not hiding from anyone. I -- Briscoe grabs him by the shirt, hauls him out the back way.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: You stay out of this, or I'll lock you up myself damnit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem picks Michael out of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You. You'll be responsible. (to soldiers) Get him a torch. Michael walks out into the square. One of the soldiers returns with a burning torch, gives it to Michael. Bethlehem looks at the town, then at Michael.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Set that flag on fire. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ON MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It's killing him, but Michael sets the torch to the flag.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Now throw it through the window of your ‘post office.' CRASH! The TORCH goes through the post office WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: ON FORD
dialogues.text: Struggling to get out, but Briscoe blocks his way.

dialogues.speaker: ON BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: As flames grow, he takes one last look around.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: The United States doesn't exist. That flag is an abomination. Briscoe steps forward, attempts to diffuse the situation.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: General Bethlehem. (as Bethlehem turns) We're gathering the tribute, sir. Can I take your wagons? Bethlehem decides not to kill anyone, looks to Getty.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Make sure that fire doesn't go out. The General joins Briscoe. Tears on his cheeks, Ford watches the post office burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem relaxes with his officers as wagons are loaded. Michael is just passing with a sack of grain on his shoulder, when Bethlehem looks across the street -- spies Abby and some of the other women sewing grain sacks shut.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Good Lord. That, gentlemen, is a first-rate piece of ass. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Michael overhears. He looks over as Bethlehem's men nod in agreement. Michael sees that they're talking about Abby.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Tell the Sheriff I want to be introduced. She does not belong in a mudhole like this. One of the men hurries off. It's concern for Abby, not for his manhood that makes him step forward.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (looks over) You again?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: That's my wife, General. She's a married woman.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Do you know what system of government we have here, son? (as Michael shrugs) A feudal system. Like the Middle Ages. With lords and vassals. That's you and me. Those lords, they had some ideas. If a vassal got married, it was the lord's right, his right, to sleep with the bride on the wedding night.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Me and Abby have been married for three years.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Sorry, but I wasn't invited to the wedding. Now, you've already done me one favor, son. Don't let this be a black mark on an otherwise perfect record.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Another woman has pointed out to her what's going on. She can't hear what's being said, but she watches, concerned. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: We'll be civilized about this. I want you to give me your blessing.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Sir, I can't. You can't.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Can't? I'm tired of can't. We had a great nation once. Do you know what made it that way? I can! Till the weak came along. The 'I can'ts' destroyed us. But I'm going to make us strong again. I'm going to be the father of a new nation. (draws his sword) Do you know why it will be me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael looks to Abby as she starts across the street.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Because I can! The SWORD WHISTLES down. Accompanied by an anguished cry:

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Michael! Abby rushes forward, but she's blocked by Getty and another man. She cries out again and again. Filled with impotent fury, Briscoe squeezes out the words

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: You didn't have to!--

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Didn't have to what, Sheriff? Three Holnist soldiers draw down on Briscoe. Bethlehem circles, menacing on his horse.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Your people seem seditious. You seem seditious. Briscoe stares down at Michael's crumpled form. Abby wails. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Aw, Michael... Briscoe might go after Bethlehem despite the odds.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: What am I seeing here? I'm waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: (burying his anger) Man came through here. With mail. Said he was a postman. Said the government had been restored back east.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: What government? From out of the crowd!-- a voice. Ford.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: The United States government. Bethlehem whirls his horse at the noise.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Who said that? Not waiting for an answer, Getty charges the crowd, knock one of the onlookers down. A dead silence. Bethlehem frowns, thinks it over a minute.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Which way did he go? (a beat) Do not make me ask again.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: (lies) East.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (to Getty) Send a patrol east. Send three more south, north and west. (to Briscoe) They'd better find him east.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Holnist army rides out. Overcome by grief, tied at the wrists, Abby stumbles behind one of the wagons.  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the smoking ruins, Ford pulls on a blue shirt, his homemade postal flag on the shoulder. As Briscoe steps up, Ford shows him a bundle of singed, but intact letters

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I managed to save these.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: (ve: shirt) Take that thing off, Johnny. You want to die, too? Ford shoves the letters in a makeshift bag, then climbs onto his waiting pony.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I'm headed south. With the mail.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: (grabs harness) Don't be a damn fool.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: What kind should I be?... Haw! Ford digs his heels into the pony and is off in a flash doing damn near a buck seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail call. The Postman stands in front of the torn screen. Hoping for glory by association, the smiling Mayor stands beside him. The ragged people of Benning clamor in front. Kids smile up at him as he calls out names:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Rachel Clark! (as she's there) Charlie Sykes! (as he's there) Graham Druitt!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: G.D. died last winter of flu. The Postman nods, sticks the letter back in his bag.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: That's it for now, folks. There'll be more once a real system is in place. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As usual, The Postman is assaulted with questions.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Tell us about President Starkey!

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What about New York City? Did they survive the plague?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Survive? They got Broadway up and running again. There's a kid doing Andrew Lloyd Webber like you wouldn't believe. An older woman sheds a happy tear -- this is wonderful news.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: How much is it to mail a letter?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) A buck seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: That sounds awful cheap.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: The catch is the only currency recognized are silver American coins minted before 1964 and two dollar bills. Look for Thomas Jefferson. Of course, food is always acceptable as barter. The moment is split by a SIREN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long double-line of Holnist Cavalry stand in formation in front of the city walls made from stacks of crushed cars. On top, a SKINNY SENTRY CRANKS the SIREN while a CHUBBY SENTRY watches. Bethlehem rides through them with Abby in tow!-- her wrists tied by a rope which is looped around the pommel o Bethlehem's saddle. Her face is bruised, her bottom lip split. Bethlehem reins up, puzzled by the apparent stall. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: (cides up; salutes) They won't open the gates, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: They say they got a representative of the restored United States in there. They say this army is illegal. They say -- The Chubby Sentry answers from the top of the palisade.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY SENTRY
dialogues.text: Drop dead and go to hell! The Chubby Sentry disappears back behind cover. Bethlehem remains controlled, but his manner becomes deadly.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: The Romans had an expression they used to scare their children. ‘Hannibal ad portas!' -- Hannibal is at the gates. Do you know who Hannibal was? (as she doesn't answer) Of course not. A pretty girl like you wouldn't know a thing. (to Getty) Colonel Getty, get some men up there and open that gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor hurries over, The Postman following reluctantly The Mayor spots the Sentries up on the parapet.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?! Open the gates!

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY SENTRY
dialogues.text: Government's restored! We don't have to take their crap anymore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Holnists scale the gates. They're near the top when the Skinny Sentry appears. He FIRES an ARROW. Hit through the shoulder, one Holnist falls. The other jumps.  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chubby and Skinny duck down behind the safety of the walls, trading high-fives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem orders his men to pull back. He shakes his head, a quiet rage building. But he knows there's no military threat here. It's going to be a massacre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Climbing an inside ladder, the Mayor slams the Chubby Sentry against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Idiots!

dialogues.speaker: CITIZEN
dialogues.text: (realizing; scared) They're gonna kill us all. The Mayor peers out through an observation hole. The Postman and several others join him.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY SENTRY
dialogues.text: No! Let's fight them!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: With what? We got five guns maybe 20 rounds of ammo in the whole town! How do we fight them with that?! The Postman watches the Holnists prepare for attack.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You don't. Negotiate a settlement. Give them extra supplies. The men look at each other. Sounds reasonable enough.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Okay. You're a government rep. You go tell them. The look on The Postman's face says it all.  60 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They open enough to let the Postman ride out, then close behind him. He sits nervously on his horse waving a white flag. He's met, dismounts and is led to a command post where Bethlehem is studying a rough map of the town.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Make it quick. I've got an attack to coordinate.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: General, um, they've asked me to negotiate a peace treaty. The last time he and Bethlehem were face-to-face, the Postman had a shaved head, was dressed in rags, and was covered with cuts and bruises. Bethlehem can't place him, but there's something familiar all the same.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't think so, sir. I --

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (scans uniform) You're the Postman, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: watches from the flap of Bethlehem's tent. The guard sees and shoves her back inside.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM AND THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Bethlehem flicks at the uniform flag shoulder patch.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: The restored United States. Do these people really believe that shit? Who are you really? Although he wants to confess everything, something tells The Postman he has to try to brass it out.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I am a United States Postman. Authorized by order 417 of the restored Congress to -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: I was at the Battle of Georgetown. I watched the White House burn to the ground. Don't try to sell me on any restored U.S...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: The new capital is based in Minneapolis. Inside the Hubert Humphrey Metrodome. You know, where the Vikings used to play?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You're funny. Now, what are the terms?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: They'1l open the gate and give you double what they usually give. Just don't hurt anybody. This was all a misunderstanding. Bethlehem thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby tracks the guard's silhouette through the canvas. Her eyes search the tent -- land on the cot in the corner and focus on its heavy, wooden legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem has decided.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Appreciate your offer, Postman. Problem is, you're in no position to negotiate. These people made it through the bugs and the riots and the three year winter. But they're not going to survive you. Bethlehem looks to Getty and nods. Getty motions to a gunner. The MONSTER GUN is FIRED. Just as a SHELL EXPLODES against the gates --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby brings the heavy wooden cot leg down on the unsuspecting guard's head.  64 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cavalry ride through roiling smoke into the open town Horrified, The Postman steps forward, but rifles are on him. All he can do is watch. The Mayor is the first to go down.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Law six, justice can be dictated. (to soldiers) Kill him. And kill the restored United States with him. Bethlehem turns his attention to the battle. A CAPTAIN steps forward with gun raised.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (by rote) In accordance with law eight and by the authority of Emergency Order 46, you are hereby -- A CRACK of RIFLE FIRE. The Captain's forehead explodes and he falls to the ground. Shocked, Bethlehem whirls for the source of the GUNFIRE. Abby! FIRING from a position behind a supply wagon. But even as Bethlehem turns, an ARROW SINGS in and lodges in his arm. Fired from a pocket of sentries up on the palisade. Bethlehem bellows in outrage and pain. The Postman takes advantage of the moment of chaos to gra the fallen Captain's gun. He pulls a Holnist rider from his horse and swings into the saddle. The unhorsed rider goes for his gun. But once more SHOTS RING OUT and he goes down. Bethlehem ducks as another BULLET ZINGS close. Too close.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Get her. Two soldiers move forward. Suddenly The Postman's HORSE comes THUNDERING -- tramplin the Holnist nearest him. The other Holnist hears, looks back, sees The Postman coming and takes aim just as The Postman brings his gun t bear. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Holnist FIRES first. We don't see the hit. Just watch as The Postman FIRES an answering ROUND. The Holnist goes down. The Postman reins up alongside the wagon. Grunting with pain, he reaches down, takes Abby's arm and swings her up behind him. Then digs his heels in for all he's worth. More Holnists come on the run. They FIRE. The HORSE SNORTS in pain. He's hit. But The Postman urges him on, heading into the woods. Bethlehem snaps off the arrow shaft and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Colonel Getty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby is concerned as the horse slows to a trot.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: We can't stop now. They'll be coming after us. The Postman's head lolls forward. She feels something on her hand, pulls it back smeared with blood. The Postman's shot in the belly. The horse is failing. Near death. We hear the sound of PURSUING CAVALRY. Abby urges the horse off the road. When the thicket grows too dense, Abby jumps down. She catches The Postman as he slides off, easing him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (disoriented) Abby... Abby shushes him. She pulls on the horse's bridle to force him farther along. But it's no good, the wounded horse goes down on its knees. And five RIDERS THUNDER past. Fooled. All but the SIXTH, who pulls up to listen. In the deep b.g., flames lick at the billowing black smoke. The town is burning. The HORSE WHINNIES: in its death throes. Abby panics, tries to quiet the horse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Sixth Soldier has heard the suffering horse. He draws his rifle from the saddle boot and starts into the thicket.

dialogues.speaker: ON ABBY AND POSTMAN
dialogues.text: The Postman lies unconscious on the ground. Abby sits beside him, rifle in hand. The Sixth Soldier appears.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Don't move. He hesitates at first. Then dismounts and moves toward her. Abby cocks the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: SIXTH SOLDIER
dialogues.text: If you'd had a bullet, you'd a used it by now. Moving closer still, he doesn't see the BRANCH pulled bac in The Postman's hand until it SNAPS hard into his face. He stumbles back.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You're right. Abby dashes out, rifle in hand. She swings for the bleachers. The butt catches the side of the Sixth Soldier's head. He falls hard. The Postman's eyes flutter. Dazed, he watches as Abby pilfers through the Soldier's gear. She takes everything of value: a knife, bullets, a canteen. His eyes flutter closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowflakes swirl. Abby lays a sapling travois beside The Postman. He groans as she rolls him onto it, tucks a blanket around him. Using all the strength God gave her, Abby lifts one end, gets it high enough to hitch it to th Sixth Soldier's horse. As Abby leads the horse away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snow has increased. A Holnist patrol moves down the road, disappears around a bend. A beat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Abby appears, leading the horse and travois. She crosses the road and disappears into the woods. A moment later, she reappears with a pine branch which sh uses to brush at the snow, obscuring their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riding into a blizzard, Abby leads the way up a zigzag path. A valley opens up below. The unconscious Postman lies bundled on the travois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little square shape just visible beyond a creek. Abby leads the horse and travois-bound Postman to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One room. Dirt floor. The WINDOWS RATTLE in the WIND. Snow falls through a hole in the roof. The wooden DOOR BURSTS back and Abby enters. Half-frozen, she leads the horse and the travois right inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire has been lit. The Postman lies unconscious, his shirt open as Abby washes around his wound. She pulls the shirt back to clean his chest. The material falls away and Abby stops short. There -- high on his biceps -- a branded "8." She stares in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman lies on a cot below the window. He's conscious, but pale as a ghost. Abby brings him a bowl of soup. Very thin soup. Stirring it with a spoon, The Postman smiles at Abby.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. She turns her back on him without a word. The Postman tries an exchange just the same. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't think I ever had water soup before. Maybe next time we could try it with a little sand? (as she doesn't respond) Dirt? Wood? (as she doesn't smile) A twig garnish? She goes about her business in silence.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You used to think I was funny.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: They killed Michael.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. He takes a spoonful of soup and she comes to him.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: How sorry are you?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean? Her right hand flashes out, holds a knife up under his chin.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What's with you?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You got the mark of eight on you. A long beat. Finally, he swallows the soup in his mouth. The action presses his Adam's apple against the blade.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: A mark doesn't mean I'ma --

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You're a liar. I should've let you die.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Then, why didn't you? If she knows, she's not ready to say yet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You were with Bethlehem. Does that make you one of them? Abby considers this, The Postman's gaze flickers down to the spoon he still holds in his hand. Taking one last stab at a joke.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (re: the spoon) Don't make me use this. Abby doesn't laugh. But she does relent. She steps away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hunting shack huddled against the south side of a low rise. Beyond the rise, a pass. But there's no negotiating it now. It's completely snowed in. And another storm is on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIND HOWLING in the b.g. The Postman lies back on his cot. The little shack has been scoured clean. Abby stares listlessly at the fire. The silence is torture. The Postman tries to strike up a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Wind's come up. (no response from Abby) Getting colder too. Must be another storm -- Abby gets up and throws a log on the fire.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I didn't mean for you to --

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Your legs are going to rot off if you don't try to walk.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm hurt. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You're lazy.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Lazy?! I got a hole in my stomach. I'm weak. The two big meals around here are grass and snow. And we're running out of grass. As the two of them glare at each other for a moment. Abby starts to put on her coat.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Abby doesn't answer. She picks up the rifle and starts to lead the horse outside.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You're not leaving me here, are you? Abby is out the door without a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON The Postman in the window as she continues past. He watches a moment, suddenly grimaces. A GUNSHOT. The THUD of a BODY SLAMMING to the GROUND. Abby has shot the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiny tracks in the snow, leading away from the shack. Abby struggles to make the monumental climb from the shac to the top of the rise where she can get a clear view of the pass. PAN PAST her UP TO the top of the rise. It's a clear day -- but the pass is still snowed-in. No sign of winter receding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby ladles a meager portion of horse meat stew into a bowl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: This is the last of it. She walks with the bowl past The Postman -- who sits on his cot with arms outstretched -- and pointedly sets the bowl on the table.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (mumbled) Give me a break... Abby starts putting on layer after layer of clothing.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I'm going to check the pass.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Why are you in such a hurry to get out of here? I can think of worse places. And worse company to -- And with the SLAM of the DOOR she is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few flakes of snow have begun to drift down. The Postman sits at the window -- starts to play tic-tac-toe in the frost. But then it dawns on him:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You can't play tic-tac-toe with yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disoriented, Abby stops to take stock of her surround- ings. But she can't make anything out -- the snowfall is too thick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire is dying. The food untouched. The Postman sits in bed staring anxiously out the window. The snow has turned into a blizzard. He runs Abby's red ribbon through his hands.  81 82 83 84 85 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby trudges along heavily. She stumbles as the ice covering the stream breaks beneath her feet.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman hears her call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and out steps The Postman. In pain, he staggers around the back of the cabin -- in search of her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby looks up, sees him coming. The Postman collapses across from her. Both prone, they're also nearly nose-to- nose.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I can't help you. Finally, he pulls himself to his knees. She does the same. They climb each other to a standing position. Arm- in-arm, they start for the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby sits huddled in blankets. The fire is blazing. The Postman steps over, sets the once-again-hot bowl of stew before her. She considers the food a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I told you that's all there was.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: That's why you should have it.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I knew you could walk.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You're weird, you know that?  86 87 88 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman lies in bed, stares through the hole in the roof. A full moon is on the rise. Abby lies in her own makeshift bed, also awake. After a long silence:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: We walked on the moon once, Abby.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: So? What good is that now?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Obviously you've forgotten Tang and microwave ovens. (a beat) Your face looks pretty. Abby looks up.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Not so bruised.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Look, there's something you'd better know. You're going to find out soon enough. I'm pregnant. (a long beat) It's Michael's baby. You're just the body father.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: How do you know it's mine and not Bethlehem's?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: He tried with me almost every night. He couldn't do it. So he beat me. Said it was my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby stands atop the low rise -- looking out to the pass. Spring has come to the mountains. At long last the snow is starting to recede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman kneels by the bank, sharpening a knife to clean the fish he's caught. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then, he catches his reflection in the water. Tangled beard. Matted hair. Is that him? He suddenly starts sharpening the knife with renewed vigor. We get a sense he's not going to use it on the fish.

dialogues.speaker: HANDS
dialogues.text: plunge into the water, pull splashfuls up. We START ON The Postman's back, then ARC AROUND as he washes his face He's just finished shaving off his beard with the hunting knife. He's nicked-up, but it's a definite improvement and he smiles in satisfaction -- until he sees -- Abby, reflected in the water.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Abby. The Postman whips around to see her standing there.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What is it? What's wrong? Is it the baby?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: The pass is clear. It's time to go. Behind her, he sees the cabin is on fire. Takes off running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire is blazing. The hunting shack is too far gone to save. The Postman turns around.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What happened? He's nonplused to find Abby standing beside a pile of their neatly-packed gear.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You got our stuff out.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Of course. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Of course? I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I set the fire.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Am I missing the point here?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You didn't think we'd stay here forever, did you? (The Postman has no response) I'd appreciate if you'd walk with me long enough to find someplace safe for the baby. Then we can split up. (a beat) You shaved. The Postman has all but forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It looks nice. Before he can respond, she's heading off toward the pass, leaving The Postman to shake his head at the absurdity of it all. He shouts after her.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You're really weird, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying their gear, Abby and The Postman walk across a meadow of wild flowers, headed for an old road.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Have you ever heard of St. Rose, Abby?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I've heard people talk. I've heard lots of names. Bliss. Hesperia. New Eden. Sheriff Briscoe says it's a fantasy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: He's wrong. St. Rose is out there. And I'm going to find it.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: But you're The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Look, I'm nobody, Abby. I'm just... Before he can come clean -- they see a distant RIDER coming hard. The Postman unslings the rifle, slides a round into the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: This is what I hate. Strangers. Do you say 'hi' or do you blow their head off? Do they want to share what they got or take what you have? And if they want to take, how far are you willing to go to stop them? Damn it. (to the Rider) All right. That's far enough. The Rider pulls up short, wearing a blue home-made uniform.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: We don't want any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: RIDER
dialogues.text: Me neither, mister. The Postman is taken aback. The Rider, a girl, pulls off her cap, mops it across her brow. Maybe 14, we'll always know her by her Ponytail. Abby registers the uniform first.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What are you?

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL, (RIDER)
dialogues.text: Carrier 18. U.S. Postal Service. Got any mail? Lowering the rifle, The Postman looks over at Abby, back to Ponytail.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: That's impossible. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: Ain't you heard of The Postman?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: No, tell us.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: He's only the greatest man who ever lived. He crossed the wasteland, shook his fist at the enemy and spit in the eye of General Bethlehem himself. He's back east with President Starkey right now.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Who told you all this?

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: Postmaster Ford Lincoln Mercury. He's in direct contact with the restored congress.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Direct contact... I don't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: (growing irritated) Do you have mail, or don't you?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You said Carrier Eighteen. That mean there's eighteen of you?

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: Thirty-two. As of midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oregon's main post office. A silver Airstream, fifty mobile homes and rusty Winnebagos resting on flat tires. Flying from a pole: the flag of the restored United States. A young recruit is ringing a bell on the top of a Winnebago. Ford walks along an RV boulevard. He's joined by two young carriers, RED and Chubby (the sentry from Benning). All wear hip, personalized variations of the official uniform.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: You got another letter? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They come around the corner to where seven young recruits wait. They're joined by another twenty carriers.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: More recruits?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Seven of them. They're coming from everywhere. Ford looks them over in satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: Did you get a letter or didn't you? Ford smiles, reaches into his pocket. He pulls out a creased sheet of paper. Chubby grins.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Gather ‘round, everybody. Got another letter here. Came in last night. Buzzing with excitement, the carriers gather around Ford.

dialogues.speaker: SOUTH END OF BOULEVARD
dialogues.text: Ponytail leads Abby and The Postman. They come up in the back of the crowd. Flanked by Red and Chubby, Ford stands on the hood of a car, letter in hand. The Postman taps a clueless YOUNG CARRIER on the back.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What's all this?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CARRIER
dialogues.text: Postman sent Ford another letter. He's gonna read it.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: (reading) ‘Hello, all postal carriers.'

dialogues.speaker: CARRIERS
dialogues.text: (a ritual) Hello! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I'm here in Minneapolis with President Starkey, but my thoughts are with you. Remember, nothing worth doing can be done overnight. Keep your chins up and do your best not to get shot. Signed, The Postman. A buzz goes through the crowd. Ponytail looks over.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: His letters are always kind of short. Abby and The Postman exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: (looks up) Hold on now. There's a P.S... Anybody know what P.S. stands for? The Postman raises his hand. Ford looks his way. His mouth drops as he realizes. In silence, he walks over to The Postman. They embrace and all the weight Ford's been carrying on his young shoulders suddenly falls to The Postman. The kid nearly collapses.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: Holy shit...

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: That would be H.S., Chubby.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: I seen him once when I lived in Benning. It's The Postman! Word goes through the crowd like a wave. The Postman takes the letter, reads.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: P.S. Ford knows what to do. Ford shrugs sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Guess you want to talk about this? The Postman takes Ford by the elbow. They disappear into the tent. The carriers just staring after them, awestruck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: I found him! I found him! They clamor around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman and Ford.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: President Starkey? Minneapolis? Ford knows what to do?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I thought you were dead.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: So? I'm not making the connection. What's all this then?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I lied. I told people you were in contact with me.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Because I didn't want it to end.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't know how long I can stay, Ford. President Starkey will send word one day and I'1l have to move on. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Sure. But you'll stay till he sends word? Right? The Postman can't answer, just turns and walks out of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As The Postman exits, Chubby leads the carriers in a salute. The Postman actually turns a moment to see if someone else is standing behind him. He looks back, sees the young, shining faces. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Aw, don't do that. Hands down. Their hands go down in one crisp military move. The Postman looks at Abby, to Ford as he exits the tent. The kid is craving reassurance.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: You'll stay 'til President Starkey sends word, right? Right?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, till he sends word, right. Ford smiles, gestures to the carriers.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Could you say a few words? The Postman looks over at the carriers. They quiet under his gaze, immediately respectful. The problem is, he has no idea what to say. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Two plus two equals four. The cheering is tumultuous. The Postman picks Abby out of the cheering crowd -- the look on her face says it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guts of the operation. Several carriers are busy sorting and bagging letters. It goes out pinned to a clothesline which crisscrosses back and forth. Everyone follows as Ford takes The Postman on a tour. There are hushed whispers among those who are seeing him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: We bring all the mail here first. We sort it, group it and then it goes out. So far we got thirty routes. Ford leads The Postman and Abby into another Winnebago. Chubby and Red and Ponytail follow. Those that can't fit just peer in through the windows.  95 96 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old manual crank printing press is working away. Ford proudly removes a sheet, shows it to The Postman. A caricature of eight evil Holnists, forming a figure eight Beneath: "Unite Against Holnist Tyrraney!"

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You spelled tyranny wrong.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: (low, to Red) Boy, he's smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seven young Recruits seen earlier stand in a line. They're joined by OLD GEORGE, every day of 75 years old. Ponytail holds up her hand, swears them in.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL/RECRUITS
dialogues.text: Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night... As they finish, The Postman and Ford pass by. The Recruits salute. Shaking his head, The Postman's about to salute back when he spots Old George. George has a faded purple "AIRBORNE" tattoo on his arm and a twinkle in his eye. There's an old crow on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGE
dialogues.text: Seventy-five, sir. The Postman looks over at Ford, who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Can you ride?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nope. Can't walk too good, either.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGE
dialogues.text: I know stuff. The Postman looks at Ford again. Then: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (re: tattoo) When did you get that?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGE
dialogues.text: 1970. A girl with eyes as big as saucers did me in a little town called Saigon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carriers move items out of the trailer. The camp is buzzing as usual. The Postman looks on -- sees Abby passing by.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Abby --

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Yes? He's got her attention, just doesn't know what to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Ford wants me to have his trailer. Said it's the best one.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I'm on the other side of town.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I got plenty of room here. She shakes her head, and then walks away. The Postman watches her disappear into the bustle of the camp.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: So much for the uniform theory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same sun sets on the Holnist camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem once again at his easel with palette in hand. He's trying another style -- Impressionism -- and it's worse than the last. He looks over as Getty and Gibbs approach with a PRISONER. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: What do you think, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Can't tell what it is if you stand too close. The colors all kinda run together, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Yes... Bethlehem looks away from his painting to see Gibbs and Getty flanking a scared, blue-clad mail carrier. For an instant, mistakes him for:

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn't our old friend the U.P.S. man.

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: We captured him on the Oregon border. Realizing, Bethlehem turns the face from side-to-side.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: CARRIER, (PRISONER)
dialogues.text: Carrier Twelve. United States, um, Postal Service. Getty sets some of the Carrier's anti-Holnist propaganda onto Bethlehem's field table. Bethlehem picks it up. It's hard to say what he's thinking. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: I want the camp struck at dawn. We're moving north.

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Bethlehem looks back to Carrier Twelve.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (chilling) You spelled tyranny wrong.  100 101 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten letter carriers are on horseback. Among them, Red and Ponytail. Ford and The Postman are also on horses. Each rider salutes The Postman, then gets a sheaf of anti- Holnist propaganda from Ford.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I wish they'd stop saluting. It's annoying him. As Chubby rides up. The Postman catches his right wrist as he attempts to salute. So Chubby salutes with the left hand instead. As they line up:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Just stay safe and remember. The mailman's more important than the mail.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: Boy, he's smart. The sun just peeks up over the horizon. At that signal, the carriers thunder off, the ground trembling under them The look on their faces. The glory of it all. They're alive! The Postman hesitates, watches after them a moment.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What the hell? Urging his horse forward, he rides after them. With them. And then, like an exploding firework, each postman shoots off in a separate direction. Headed for all points of the compass and some in between.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks down on the gathered crowd from his horse and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: For President Starkey and the First Congress of the Restored United States, I officially declare Postal Station 10... What's the name of this town?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG LEADER
dialogues.text: We never named it.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (thinks; smiles) I officially declare Postal Station 10 in Elvis, Oregon, open for business!  102 103 104 105 106 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eye-blink of a town. Ponytail stands on a crate reading names and handing letters to the grateful people massed around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red and Chubby finish mail call, exchange an amazed look as they're offered a platter of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon hangs low over an interstate. A rider is silhouetted by the silvery orb, looking like some post- apocalyptic Don Quixote. It's The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen FROM the porch, a rider gallops hard on the road beyond. A LITTLE BOY comes rushing out, letter in hand. The boy pulls up short; realizes the rider is already too far gone. The boy's shoulders sag; he's crushed.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOY
dialogues.text: I missed him. It's an almost psychic moment as the rider reins up in th distance and turns back around. A frozen beat and he starts galloping back down the road. Fearless, the boy holds out the letter. The rider closes; it's The Postman. The boy stretches out as far as he can. Without breaking stride, The Postman leans out of the saddle, snatches the letter as he passes. The boy watches after him -- knows what he's going to be when he grows up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Briscoe huffs and puffs his big frame up the ladder and onto the top of the palisade.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Phil, this better not be another of your U.F.O.'s. He looks where the sentry points. The Postman waits at the gate, behind him on horseback: Ford and Abby. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm back! And I got mail.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: (amazed) I'll be damned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman rides with Briscoe, hurrying to stay alongsid him. Half the town jogs along behind them.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Bethlehem is offering a 1000 pounds of gold to whoever brings you in. Dead or alive.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Thank God it wasn't a carton of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: I'd have shot you myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pine View is throwing a party. It's in full swing. A couple of guitars. A banjo and a trombone. Everyone dances. The Postman walks with Briscoe, sees Mrs. March as her letter is read to her. Catches a glimpse of Abby dancing with Ford. He seems, for the first time, truly happy. For that matter, so does Briscoe.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Things are getting better. Getting better all the time. (a beat) I don't know who you are, but I do know I was wrong about you. The Postman smiles, reaches in his bag for an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Got a letter for you, Sheriff. Briscoe turns it over in his hands, looks up in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: It's from my sister. I thought she was dead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You thought wrong. Briscoe has tears in his eyes. The Postman continues on, embarrassed but affected.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE
dialogues.text: The Postman taps Ford's shoulder, wants to cut in on him and Abby. Ford steps aside. A beat before Abby decides it's okay. They begin. Her eyes are on her feet, careful that she doesn't take a misstep. But his eyes are on her. And over it all, BLEEDING IN, the sound of HOOF BEATS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mail carrier, Red, rides like the devil himself was in pursuit. Almost. It's Getty and three Holnists.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE
dialogues.text: They whirl as the tempo picks up. The Postman pulls Abby in closer. Her eyes now move up to his.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: They're closing in on the terrified Red.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE
dialogues.text: Abby and The Postman. The chemistry is undeniable.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: RIFLES CRACK. SHOT in the back, Red throws back his arms. Letters flutter from the mail bag over his shoulder; he seems to glide along that way forever.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE
dialogues.text: The Postman looks at Abby; she's so beautiful. Like only a pregnant woman can be. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Tell me about the baby, Abby. I want to know. Abby snaps out of the dream she's in. This isn't right. Breaking away, she heads off. As he watches her go:

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Red falls from his horse. One of the soldiers scoops up his mailbag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By lantern, Bethlehem and Getty watch as Gibbs sorts through the contents of the confiscated mailbag.

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Births and deaths, the weather, gossip. There's nothing here.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Nothing? Everything is here. Am I the only one who sees that? (to Gibbs) Get out! Gibbs hurries away, leaving Bethlehem and Getty alone.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Give the people back their hope and their dreams won't be far behind. Bethlehem sees Getty waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: What is it, Getty? Getty hands Bethlehem a sheet of paper -- something Gibbs missed. It's a propaganda sheet featuring a caricature of The Postman leading a few carriers against Bethlehem and his army -- represented as Hitler and the Nazis. The caption underneath reads: "Ride Against the Holnist Tide!" (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (crumpling the paper) A military man, especially a commander, should keep a journal. After he's gone, it's the only real defense against the slander that arises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old George sits hunched over a home-made shortwave radio with a joint in his mouth. The Postman sits beside him, listening as STATIC pours from an old car SPEAKER.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Who do you talk to?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGE
dialogues.text: Not a soul in seven years of trying. But I will. The Postman steps to a telescope pointing up through a hole in the trailer ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGE
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Take a look. (offering joint) Want some?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: No. No thanks. Hey, don't let the kids see that. George nods and goes on playing with the dials -- searching for a voice in the void. The Postman focuses on the moon.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was an aerospace engineer. I helped design the Galileo space station. (scanning sky) I dream it's orbiting Earth forever. With a dozen human skeletons all grinning at each other. Laughing at us down here. There's an urgent KNOCKING on the trailer door. Ford appears.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What is it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: It's Red. He's overdue.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: That makes five. All on Southern routes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five dead mail carriers have been laid out on the asphalt Bethlehem walks the line, looking for his elusive arch- enemy.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: No. No. Not him. No. (looks to soldiers) Children. I want a man and you bring me children!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful day. Ponytail rounds a bend at a lope -- and then -- her eyes widen in terror. She jerks the reins; the horse rears in protest. Ahead: the truck stop. The five mail carriers hang upside down from the roof's overhang. A macabre sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIGHTING ON Ponytail. A hand comes INTO FRAME and brings the rifle barrel down. It's --

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Not yet. General wants the message to get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN UP FROM The Postman's dusty boots TO his grimly determined face as he strides through camp and stops at Old George's trailer. He moves OUT OF FRAME, revealing -- Abby and Ponytail in the b.g.  115 116 117 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As usual, Old George is hunkered down before his short wave. He looks as the door opens and The Postman enters.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Tell me about the other stuff you know... George crosses the trailer, opens a cabinet. Inside: twenty odd guns plus the parts for several more. The CROW CAWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. An old flag ruffles outside the post office -- the only new structure in town. Old George sweeps the porch as a patrol of ten Holnist soldiers ride into town. George makes no move to flee as they near. As they rein up across from him he just smiles and continues sweeping. Sensing it, the Holnist officer looks up. There, on the roof, stands The Postman. Ford and Briscoe flank him -- along with twenty mailmen and locals, armed with guns, bows and rocks. As the soldiers raise their rifles, the roofies OPEN FIRE George whips up a sawed-off SHOTGUN. BOOM! Caught in the storm, the ten soldiers go down. Grim, The Postman looks to Ford as the locals cheer. George resumes sweeping. The mailmen climb down to strip the weapons off the dead.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Ford, I want you to get rid of the bodies. I don't want these people blamed for what we did. Ford nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two sentries guard the east. They peer into the gloom at the sound of a WAGON APPROACHING. It sounds like it's coming fast.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Halt! Identify yourself! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WAGON
dialogues.text: tearing along. Ford at the reins, urging the horses to all possible speed. Then he stands, leaps to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRIES
dialogues.text: They raise their rifles as the riderless wagon looms out of the night. They each get off a SHOT before being forced to dive out of the way. The wagon continues on, down to...

dialogues.speaker: HOLNIST CAMP
dialogues.text: A soldier finally grabs hold of one of the halters and brings the wagon to a stop. Half-dressed, Bethlehem steps up. A tarp covers the back upon which is written...

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (reading) Postage due... Bethlehem yanks away the tarp to reveal the 10 dead Holnist soldiers. The men around Bethlehem exchange looks, can't believe it. Bethlehem bellows in rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford, hidden in the woods, smiles at the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem steps forward and shouts his challenge into the night.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You want a war? I'll give you a war. I was born for it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem's words reach Ford, his smile fades. He's just a scared boy. He kicks his horse into a gallop and rides away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the fog, the sound of hollow HOOF BEATS. The Postman rides past the shapes of airplanes. Standing silent. Forever grounded. The ghosts of the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford is swearing in four new recruits.

dialogues.speaker: ON FORD AND RECRUITS
dialogues.text: As they repeat after him we realize they've changed the oath a bit.

dialogues.speaker: FORD/RECRUITS
dialogues.text: Neither snow, nor heat, nor gloom of night. Through bandit's hell, through fire fight. Through flood and plague we cannot fail. No Holnist trash will stop the mail.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: riding his weary mount into town, saddlebags bulging with mail. He pauses by the new recruits long enough to hear the words they're saying. As he dismounts, a fresh-faced carrier takes the bridle. The Postman's well past the point of fatigue. He's living on pure adrenaline.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Get this mail sorted. Bring me a fresh horse. Something to eat. As fresh-face starts away, The Postman calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: And all the mail going South! The Postman watches as Ford shakes the hands of the new recruits. The Postman reaches for his canteen. Empty. Damn. A tin cup filled with water appears from nowhere. Abby. The Postman takes it, too tired to acknowledge the gesture.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: They changed the oath. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Ford's idea.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Figures. (scoffs) They don't think to ask who they're replacing. Or why. He drains the cup and hands it back to her. Just then, one of the new recruits, LUKE, steps over.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sir? It'd be an honor if I could shake your hand. A farmboy-type, Luke looks like a younger version of Woody. The Postman sees this, is lost in reverie. Luke still holds his hand out.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You look like... Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Well, good luck to you. Nodding in awe, Luke heads off.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Nice kid. Probably be dead in a week.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (ignores it) You're exhausted. You need rest. There's food in the trailer -- Ponytail rides by; two sacks of mail hang from her saddle pommel. The Postman grabs her horse's halter, stops her.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: Route twenty-two. I'm already an hour late. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You're grounded. Get off the horse. You know the rule.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: What rule?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Twenty-two's too far south.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: But they're waiting on their mail down there.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Get off the goddamn horse. Shocked, she does. At the same time, fresh-face comes up leading a second horse laden with mail.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (re: Ponytail's horse) Tie him off to this one. Fresh-face goes about tying the second horse to the first

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You can't keep doing this.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Riding all the routes. You're not saving anyone. The Postman climbs on Ponytail's horse, looks at Abby.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you how I got to be a postman, Abby? (doesn't give her time to answer) I don't know if you'd laugh or cry. The Postman digs in his heels. The horse gallops away, the second one following behind.  123 124 103.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A crowd of townsfolk are visible in deep b.g. Beyond them, the town of Elvis burns to the ground. The CAMERA CIRCLES AROUND the BLOODIED CARRIER until we'r looking OVER his shoulder at a firing squad led by Colone Getty and Lieutenant Gibbs. Bethlehem watches.

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Ready! The only building not on fire is the post office. A SOLDIER rides up, carrying a torch, meaning to burn it.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: The post office, General?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: No. Let it stand. All by itself. So it can remind them what it cost them.

dialogues.speaker: . GIBBS
dialogues.text: Aim! Rifles are aimed.

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Fire! Shock and dismay from the townsfolk as SHOTS RING OUT.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODY CARRIER'S FACE
dialogues.text: as he realizes he's still standing. PULL BACK to reveal nine bodies lying on the ground. Only the Bloodied Carrier is still standing. Bethlehem points at the Bloodied Carrier, crooks a finger for him. He staggers up. Bethlehem smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You think you can ride? (as the Carrier nods ) Then today's your lucky day. INT. RV PARK - AIRSTREAM —- DAY 124 Abby tends to the Bloodied Carrier. He tries to salute as The Postman enters the trailer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ford and Chubby watch and wait as The Postman goes to the boy's side.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODIED CARRIER
dialogues.text: Bethlehem says... The Postman motions it's okay as the Carrier struggles.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODIED CARRIER
dialogues.text: --. he's... headed north. He's gonna kill ten people in every town. Then burn it to the ground. For what you did... The Postman is puzzled. But Ford knows what and why.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODIED CARRIER
dialogues.text: He said to tell you Pine View's on his way. He said he'd wait there, but not for long. (breaking down) I was so scared, sir... I thought they were going to kill me, too... I wish they would have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman poised on a rise that affords a view of the gruesome spectacle below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pine View in flames. The big John Deere gun has blown several gaps into the palisade. Bethlehem watches as his army sacks the town. The people have been rounded up. The selection of the ten has begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman wheels his horse around. But Ford, Ponytail, Chubby and Luke are standing in his way.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm going to stop this.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: You can't. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Get out of my way, Ford. All of you.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) They'11 kill you. The Postman starts to ride through them. Luke, Chubby and Ponytail move their horses to block. Ford maneuvers his horse in close and grabs The Postman's harness.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Goddamnit -- The Postman jumps off his horse. Ford tackles him. The Postman shoves him away, continues on. Luke and Chubby pounce on him. With Ford's help, they hold him down.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: You can't help them!

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: There's still time, Ford! The Postman struggles. They're genuinely having trouble holding him down.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: (re: The Postman) You're hurting him. But there's no let-up.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: No, this is all my doing. I went against your orders. There's a moment of shocked surprise.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: The Holnists we killed. You told me to bury them. But I didn't. I sent Bethlehem the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Because Bethlehem has to know that we're not going to stop. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: God damn you, Ford. Those people down there are dying because of us. Because of what we did.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Bullshit. They're dying because of Bethlehem. They're dying because this is a shitty world. And if we're ever going to change it, then somebody might have to die. If I could make it be me down there I would. But I can't. A terrible SCREAM gives them all pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down below -- Holnist soldiers hold back a screaming mother as her 10-year-old boy is pulled into the line. Sheriff Briscoe is among the ten, he puts his hand on the boy's shoulder -- the picture of grace under pressure.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: My God, what have I done? (beat) We don't even know their names...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOY
dialogues.text: His eyes wide and fearful. Like a kitten's.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: (holding back the tears) We know their names. The little one's my brother. His name is Billy. A moment of stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: What Ford did was wrong. But it doesn't change anything for any of us. Does it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks to the other carriers -- it's written all over their faces -- they stand with Ponytail and Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem looks the line-up over. The firing squad stands at the ready. Bethlehem looks to the trees -- feeling something.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (to Getty) He's out there somewhere. Watching. I can feel it. Briscoe follows his gaze. He doesn't see anything, but maybe gets the same feeling. Bethlehem looks to Briscoe.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You feel it too, don't you? Didn't have to end like this, Sheriff. He knew where I'd be if he wanted to face me like a man. Instead, he's hiding like a rabbit. So much for your Postman.

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Ready! Aim! Rifles are raised. Briscoe seems to grow as he throws his shoulders back and shouts...

dialogues.speaker: BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Ride, Postman! Ride! You hear me? I said ride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WORDS ECHO. Nothing The Postman can do, but watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem's eyes go wild --

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Fire! The RIFLES BARK. Everyone falls dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something in The Postman breaks. He just lies there. The witnesses move back, taking The Postman with them.  135 136 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Briscoe lies dead. The letter from his sister blows from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman folds a letter, shoves it into an envelope. He writes "Bethlehem" across the front, starts to write a second letter. The door opens and Abby enters.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Ford thinks you're going to do something.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I am. The Postman watches as, outside, the mail carriers begin to assemble.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: If I don't, those kids are going to keep on getting themselves killed.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Ford doesn't know what it means to be a kid. He doesn't have your memories. None of them do. All they've got is the lousy world we gave them. And this is the only decent thing in it.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: What? Being a postman? It's all bullshit, Abby. All of it. (beat) I took this uniform off a skeleton to stay warm. I made up the rest to stay fed. There is no restored United States.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I knew it was something like that. The Postman fingers the brim of the cap, softens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Weird thing is, being a Postman was almost the best thing that ever happened to me... (re: red ribbon) Remember this? You left it behind that night.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I remember...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I always liked to think you left it on purpose. But maybe you just forgot it. Abby doesn't answer. She leaves instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve mail carriers, including Ford, Ponytail, Chubby, Luke and Old George, wait as The Postman steps up before them. Abby's off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Is this everybody?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: The rest are on the overdue list.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: This is everybody. (for all) Got a letter from President Starkey. An excited murmur among the carriers. Only Ford eyes The Postman suspiciously. The Postman reads:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: ‘Greetings all carriers.'

dialogues.speaker: CARRIERS
dialogues.text: Greetings, President Starkey!

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (reading) ‘I've been in contact with The Postman. I've received all the reports. I'm proud of you all.' He looks at them, doesn't need to read what's in his heart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: In dark days, in a weary world, you gave everything and asked for nothing. You beat back despair and replaced it with hope and for that your country can never repay you. But the price is too high. I won't see anymore of my bravest die. It is my duty to hereby disband the Postal Service of the restored United States. You are to burn your uniforms and The Postman is to return to Minneapolis at once. Thank you and that is all. A hushed silence. The Postman walks away. The carriers exchange tired, defeated looks. Abby just sighs, knows he's not necessarily wrong. Ford catches up with The Postman. He stares at The Postman; The Postman stares back.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: (low; fierce) The President never wrote that letter.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: If he could've that's what he would have said. Ford gestures to the second letter.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Who's the other letter to?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Bethlehem. I'm taking it to him in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Mail's private. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (stops; turns) It says it's over. It says we quit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: It says you quit. What about the oath?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Ford. How much mail can a dead postman deliver? It's over. The Postman starts to walk away again.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Then I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I can't trust you. Ford gathers courage and confronts The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: If this is the end. If this is the last piece of mail that ever gets delivered. I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Whoever takes this letter probably dies for it. Ford thrusts out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I'm still a postman. You owe it to me... I owe it to me. The Postman hesitates, studies the intense young man. Gives him the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman is packing bags onto a horse as Abby approaches.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm going to St. Rose, Abby. And I'm taking you with me. I know you don't want to hear it, but that's my child inside you. I want to see it born somewhere safe. I have a right to that, Abby. Whether you like it or not. Abby walks away. The Postman rests his head on his pack for a moment. Heavy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The CLICK of a GUN causes The Postman to lift his head an see Luke standing there.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Thought I recognized you.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: General Bethlehem said... (vaises the pistol) .«.. You should be on your knees when I do it.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn what that asshole said.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: The general is a great man.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: The general is a fucking lunatic. The Postman steps forward. Stops when the barrel of the pistol is right against his own chest.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You don't own a thought in that goddamn head of yours, do you? (a beat) You want to see a man? The Postman turns to watch as Ford starts out of camp.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: That's a man. The Postman turns, sees Luke's face fraught with confusio and emotion.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You don't understand, do you? You never will until you can think for yourself and be willing to pay the price for it. Luke stares back into The Postman's eyes. A frozen beat.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You ready? ABBY (0.S. Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Abby sits on her horse. She's witness to it all. Luke is confused and ashamed. The Postman mounts his horse and moves to Abby's side.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You're a better man than Bethlehem, Luke. I've seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some carriers drop their uniforms into a bonfire. The Postman and Abby ride up on the ridge above the RV camp. They pause to look back one last time. Across the way, on the other side, Ford is doing the same thing. As though he senses it, Ford stops and looks back. Ford raises his hand, salutes. Slowly, The Postman brings up his own hand. But he doesn't salute. He waves. Good- bye. As Ford turns away, so does The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHUBBY, PONYTAIL AND CARRIER NAMED DREW
dialogues.text: watching as The Postman and Abby disappear from sight.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: Guess Minneapolis is that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign prohibits pedestrians, horses and bicycles. The Postman and Abby ride by. The Postman no longer wears his uniform. Their gear is packed behind their saddles. As a family of transients begin to rise from where they'r camped in the breakdown lane:

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: We can't help you. We're just as lost as you are. The Postman rides on. Abby watches over her shoulder as they slowly begin to sit back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem sits waiting at his camp table. Behind him, a finished painting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: This time he's painted himself in the grand Rococo-style - as part of the Holy Family with doves and flowers and glowing rays from Heaven. It's awful. Getty and Gibbs bring in a prisoner. It's Ford!

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Good lord, what do we have here?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I'm a representative of the restored United States -- Bethlehem backhands Ford.

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: He's got a letter. Says The Postman sent it.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: A letter? Bethlehem tears open the letter and starts to read:

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
