dialogues.text: ‘Bethlehem. This letter is my testimony to the fact that there is no restored United States and there is no Postal Service.’ (laugh; grim) Then who the hell have we been fighting...? (reads on) ‘My carriers are returning home. In exchange, I'm asking you to let them be. The Postman.' Bethlehem eyes Ford with undisguised contempt.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: He expects me to believe this?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's true, sir. I was there. He disbanded the carriers and rode west. Ford turns blazing eyes to Luke -- he's been standing there all along.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Traitor... It takes a moment for the news to sink in. But it does. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Then I've won. I've won. As the assembled Holnists congratulate each other, Bethlehem looks at Luke.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You were supposed to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I couldn't get close enough. (re: Ford) This one's his second in command. Bethlehem looks Ford over.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Why doesn't that surprise me? Ford stares back. Proud. Bethlehem looks to Getty.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Bring out the one we found yesterday. They can die together. A frightened CARRIER is brought up. He wears a purple uniform with CALI sewn on the shoulder. Neither we nor Ford have seen him before. As a firing squad assembles, Ford is shoved over with him.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: CAL CARRIER
dialogues.text: Name's Clark. Postal Carrier of the restored Republic of California. Who are you? Ford looks at him a second, can't help but laugh. From Gibbs; the shout of "ready!"

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Postmaster Ford Lincoln Mercury.

dialogues.speaker: CALI CARRIER
dialogues.text: It's an honor. Bethlehem watches as Clark holds out his hand. Ford shakes it. "Aim!"

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... wait a minute! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Hold your fire! You don't know each other? (to himself, quiet anger building) This will never be over. It'll go on except I'll be fighting a goddamn ghost.

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Should we fire, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: No goddamnit. Bethlehem crumples the letter, tosses it.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: No, I won't fight a ghost. Tabula rasa, gentlemen. A clean slate. I want all mail carriers hunted down. I want The Postman found. I want him dealt with. (to Getty) Colonel, organize the scouts. (to Luke) He rode west?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of boots are walking through the water. It's The Postman. He turns over a body in the water. It wears a homemade postal uniform, a bag of mail twisted around his arm. It's a young face, one we haven't seen before. He looks up to Abby on a ridge.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't know him. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Where do you think he came from? Puzzled, The Postman shakes his head. He gently releases the body. The current takes it and they watch as it continues on its way to Postal Valhalla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family of transients are grilled by three Holnist scouts. One man points the way Abby and Bethlehem rode.  117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Littered with rubble. The wood, brick, steel and concrete of what was once a small town. Amazingly, one gray house still stands, miraculously untouched by whatever disaster visited this place. A wild-haired SQUATTER steps out on the porch as Abby and The Postman ride by. He waves hello with a .45.

dialogues.speaker: SQUATTER
dialogues.text: Howdy. Welcome to sunny California.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (re: the town) What happened here?

dialogues.speaker: SQUATTER
dialogues.text: Little accident. The ground started to shake big time and the Hanford nuclear plant went... (motions an explosion) --- 'Poof.' Destroyed everything for miles. But the sunsets are beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You ever hear of a city called St. Rose?

dialogues.speaker: SQUATTER
dialogues.text: Friend, I've never heard of St. Shit. The Squatter laughs and laughs -- like it was the funnies thing in the world. The Postman and Abby exchange a look, continue on their way.

dialogues.speaker: SQUATTER
dialogues.text: Hey, don't go! I got Monopoly in the house! Boardwalk, Park Place and the Reading Railroad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ponytail, Chubby, and Draw watching from afar. Chubby has the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: You think that's President Starkey? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ponytail takes the telescope from Chubby for a look.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure?

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: President lives in a white house. That guy's place is gray. Drew and Chubby exchange a look. That makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lightning bolt shreds the sky. It's day, but the sky is black with rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The useless towers cutting across a valley. Rain beats down, as The Postman and Abby trudge along. Up ahead, a rail-road tunnel promises shelter from the storm.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (re: the tunnel) We can rest in there. Abby is quick to agree. Out of the corner of his eye, The Postman catches a blur of movement. He turns his head quickly, but he's barely in time to see a wooden basket, attached to one of the high wires, swing from a distant tower. There's a sentry inside it. The basketed sentry whistles away at 40 mph, heading straight for an adjacent tower. In a matter of seconds, he's lost from view. The Postman looks back at Abby. She's shivering.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) I'm hungry, Postman. The Postman guides her toward the train tunnel.  148 149 150 119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby sleeps beside the fire. The Postman, silhouetted against the flames, heads toward the far tunnel exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman peers into the rain, taking in the view of a distant bridge. Abby comes to stand at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A town settled between spans of a steel truss bridge. The Columbia River rushes far below. A sentry spots Abby and The Postman approaching, blows a whistle.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Set the rifle on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: This old thing? It isn't even loaded. Where are we? The BRIDGE CITY MAYOR, a middle-aged retro-hippie, steps up.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: You're in Bridge City. Where we don't allow guns. The Postman sets down the carbine. The Guard steps over to scoop it up.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: Sentry said you were coming. The Postman stares at the Mayor a beat.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I know you. You're famous.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: I was once. Not anymore. (beat) Are you looking to cross?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: We will be. Right now, we'd just appreciate some food. (as the Mayor nods his assent) I got some kids behind me, too. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Three. (as the Mayor agrees once more) Hey, guys, come on in! I know you're out there!

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY SENTRY
dialogues.text: Boy, is he smart... As they stand, show themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog rolls in. Abby rests. 120. 150 151 Ponytail, Chubby and Drew look up gratefully as one of th citizens of Bridge City doles out bread. The Mayor steps over, hands The Postman two loaves.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: For you and your wife.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. She's not my wife. The exchange cuts Abby like a knife. She gets up and leaves. The Mayor keeps his council -- not sure what to make of this arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something, have you ever heard of a town with electric lights?

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: St. Rose?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: Never been. But they say it's a ways down on the coast.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: How far? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: Couple hundred miles at least. I couldn't say for sure. It's the discovery of a lifetime. The Postman looks to the west end of the bridge, where Abby stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You seem like a decent man. And these seem like decent people.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: We try to be.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: And this seems like a safe place.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: (intuitive) You want to leave her? The Postman looks back to the Mayor, then slowly nods.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: All of them. I'11l give you the horses and my gear. Abby's special. She's strong. Probably end up running the place.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: Why don't you take the night to think. Decide if that's what you really want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog obscures the east end. A sentry squints at the MUFFLED CLOP of HOOVES. The mist parts to reveal, seventy yards away: three Holnist scouts on horseback. Emissaries from hell. As the sentry blows a whistle...

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGE
dialogues.text: As word spreads, folks move down the bridge for a look. Eating their bread, The Postman, Abby and the carriers join them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EAST END
dialogues.text: The Mayor stands across from the lead scout -- conferring Finally, the Mayor points him back the way he came. The lead scout doesn't budge, spots The Postman in the crowd. He and The Postman seem to stare at each other forever. Then, with a flick of the reins, he's gone. The other two follow. Swallowed up by the misty evening gloom. The Postman's head swims dizzily. It's not over. The Mayor returns to dozens of nervous questions.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: They're looking for The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAN
dialogues.text: No such thing anymore.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: Man on the horse says there is. Says he thinks he's here. Says he's coming back with friends. A little BOY steps forward, sings out.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. BOY
dialogues.text: What's a postman? A silent moment. It's been so long, no one's sure how to answer. The Postman looks down at the ground. The carriers exchange deflated looks. Then...

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (stepping forward) You never heard of a postman? He shakes his head "no." Seems a shame. As The Postman looks over at Abby, she takes a page from his book.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: There used to be a postman for every street in America. They wore uniforms. And hats. Like this one... She goes to The Postman's gear, returns with his postal cap. Sets it on the boy's head.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. BOY
dialogues.text: Wow... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: My postman knew the name of every kid on my street. He knew our birthdays. He'd even find the baseballs you'd hit down the street. I can still see the smile on his face. The tip of his cap -- when he had a letter in his bag with my name on it. Mine always came just after school. You could set your watch by him. Unless you were waiting on something special -- like a present from somewhere far away or a letter from your sweetheart. Then it seemed like he'd never come. I used to think they could make time stand still. Several other listeners nod -- they're completely with her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I don't think we ever really understood what they meant to us until they were gone. Getting a letter made you feel like you were part of something bigger than yourself. No place was ever too far away for the postman. So nobody ever had to be alone. The postman was someone you could count on. Things just made more sense when they were around. (beat) That's the kind of world we used to have. A world a lot of us took for granted. And now we've got this one. And it makes me wonder!-- what kind of world do I want my child to live in? I want my child to live in a world where hopes and dreams aren't just lies you tell yourself to get through another day. I want my child, and I want my friends -- I want all of us to live in a world where you still get your mail. It's a moment before anyone speaks.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: (to The Postman) Are you The Postman? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman takes the cap off the little boy's head, touches the emblem, and answers.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: I've heard of you, man. You're famous.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess I am. And all of a sudden, I'm not wearing the right clothes. And as he puts on his cap, he accepts the mantle as well.

dialogues.speaker: PINE BOX
dialogues.text: lowered from the top of the bridge. Hands reach up to steady it and bring it gently to the ground. It's one of many. The Postman and Abby gasp as the Mayor opens the lid to reveal: 20 well-oiled rifles and 15 pistols with ammo. The Postman blinks over at the Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: Fact that we don't allow ‘em doesn't mean we don't have ‘em. We're not stupid, after all.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I've brought this on you.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: No need to be sorry. Long as we get our mail on time.

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ready for duty, sir. The Postman looks over to see Ponytail, Drew and Chubby ride up. Like him, they are back in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: The order was to burn all uniforms. The carriers look away -- sheepish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You know what to do then?

dialogues.speaker: PONYTAIL
dialogues.text: Talk to the people. Gather who's willing. Tell them it's important. Tell them we can make a difference.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY SENTRY
dialogues.text: And tell ‘em we're going to kick ass.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, tell them that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the Gorge. The three carriers, and the mounted locals thunder off the bridge and down the road. High above...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor is in the b.g. helping one of the sentries prepare the basket for travel.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: This is hard for me. (beat) Michael was the best man I ever knew. I never thought there'd be another man I could love the way I loved him. (searching for the words) I don't know why I've been so blessed. And I've tried to find a way to be thankful, but I swear, if I lose you... Her eyes start to tear and he takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Abby, do you think a lie can become the truth?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I don't know, but I believe in you. You have a gift, Postman. I saw it back in Pine View. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You made Mrs. March feel like she could see again. You made Ford feel like he was part of the world. You give out hope like it was candy in your pocket. He starts to speak. She stops him, taking his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: When you come back, we'll be waiting here for you. So you can take us to St. Rose. The Postman lets go of her hand and starts for the basket The Mayor gestures to the line of towers extending into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: There's three good-sized towns up that way. Enough folks to be a big help to you. If you can convince them to come. As The Postman steps into the basket, he makes the mistak of looking over the edge. It's a long, long way down.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: A lot higher than it looks, huh? The Postman looks at the contraption with more than a little trepidation. The Mayor grins.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: Don't tell anybody, but I like to ride the damn thing just for the hell of it. Being a city official has its perks. He winks and as he reaches for the release pin. The Postman's hand meets his there.

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: Trust me, man. This'll get you there a lot faster.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: How do I stop -- But it's too late. The Mayor releases the pin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: B.C. MAYOR
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. Good luck and Godspeed.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTERWEIGHT
dialogues.text: Plummeting into the Columbia River Gorge. The Mayor lets out a rebel yell.

dialogues.speaker: BASKET
dialogues.text: The Postman is whipped along, past the riders below. The speed exhilarating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town's gone, but the palisade remains. Chubby rides along it, exhorting the people who watch from above. But it's The Postman we hear, all the magic back in his voice

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Once more into the breach, dear friends, once more. Or close the wall with our dead. In peace nothing so becomes a man as modesty and humility. But when the blast of war blows in our ears, then imitate the action of the tiger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few makeshift structures are back up. Carrying a torch, Ponytail gallops hard into town. People wake, including Mrs. March's daughter. As Ponytail speaks to them...

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Summon up the blood. Disguise fair nature with rage and lend the eye a terrible aspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captured by a Holnist cavalry patrol, Old George and four other carriers are lined up, hands bound before them. Holnist soldiers force them to their knees as Gibbs organizes an impromptu firing squad. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Old George looks down the line. The carriers are about to break down.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGE
dialogues.text: Steady, boys, steady. And as Gibbs steps up, all hope is gone.

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: In accordance with Law Eight...

dialogues.speaker: OLD GEORGE
dialogues.text: Get on with it, you floppy-eared sonuvabitch! We see the faces of the young carriers. Defeated, bitter. But there's a sudden spark in Old George's eyes. He starts to rise. The soldiers pick up their guns and that's when they see The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Riding over the crest. Galloping toward them. Behind him, forty new mail carriers. All riding like mad. One of them carries the flag of the restored United States. Gibbs and his men run for their horses. SHOTS are FIRED. Four Holnists go down. The rest gallop away. The Postman and his carriers meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converging. The Postman with his forty-five coming from the west. Drew, Chubby, and a ragtag thirty coming from the north. And from the south, Ponytail leading a contingent of fifty! The forces converge and continue east.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army has gathered. Three hundred strong. Bethlehem and Getty stand outside the command tent, listening to a winded, frightened Gibbs. We FOLLOW Bethlehem's eyes OVER Gibbs' SHOULDERS TO the horizon, where he sees: The Postman and his army of two hundred carriers cresting a distant rise. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ... We were outnumbered, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: A least a hundred. With guns.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (feigning shock) With guns? Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: GIBBS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir...

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Looks more like two hundred to me... He steps away to get a better vantage point of the approaching army. He reaches out -- Getty hands him a pair of binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (donning a pair of leather gloves) Only thing worse than a coward is one who can't count. Lieutenant, do yourself a favor. Die well in this battle. In my army a deserter's life is a brief and unpleasant one. Bethlehem watches The Postman through the binoculars -- a hint of a smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: (to himself) At last, someone with courage enough to bring the fight to me. A Holnist soldier stands by with Bethlehem's horse. The General mounts -- the model of military calm and precision. Getty reins up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Reckoning, gentlemen. This is the day I've dreamed of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of wildflowers separates the carriers from the Holnists. The monster John Deere gun is ready for battle.  162 163 164 130.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem stands with Getty, scanning the postal line wit his binoculars. The carriers look, just spoiling for a fight. Bethlehem lowers his binoculars, smiles grimly.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: They're an eager-looking bunch. Morale's a dangerous thing. (to Getty) Bring him up. I want this postman to see how the game is played.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman, Chubby, Ponytail and Old George and all the carriers have taken positions. The Postman sights through a telescope. He scans further down the line -- then stops when he sees Ford. Bloody, beaten within inches of his life. He's shackled -- surrounded by Holnist guards. The Postman's eyes turn to stone.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (to carriers) Stay here. No one moves until I give the orders. He clicks his horse forward, toward the Holnist line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem, flanked by Getty and the Holnist Sergeant, watches as The Postman makes his approach. He reaches into his pocket, withdraws a white kerchief and holds it in the air.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Are they surrendering?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: God, I hope not. He watches for a moment as The Postman crosses the field - moving well within range of Holnist fire. Then, he coaxes his horse forward.  165 131.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem and The Postman riding toward each other. They meet when The Postman is almost three-quarters of the way over to the Holnists' side.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM AND POSTMAN
dialogues.text: As they come face-to-face.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: My little shipping clerk.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: We're both a couple of frauds. You know it; I know it. Bethlehem sneers.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Great men are made by other great men. Patton had Rommel. Grant had Lee. But I get you.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: You're no fucking general. You're a copying machine salesman. You're not even a good painter.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Are you trying to goad me into a fight?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be great if wars could be fought just by the assholes who started them? We could settle this thing right here. You and me.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: It does in your army. The Postman kicks his horse up into a gallop, and rides u the Holnist line. No one, least of all Bethlehem, is sure what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I invoke law seven of the Laws of Eight! Any man may challenge for leadership of the clan! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: What? The Postman wheels his horse around.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I_challenge you. Bethlehem is caught completely by surprise, but recovers.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You're not a Holnist. You're not a member of the clan. You don't have the right. The Postman rolls up his sleeve. He rides the Holnist lines displaying his brand for all to see. The Holnists murmur amongst themselves.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I have every right. I invoke law seven! Bethlehem can't believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I challenge for leadership of the clan! The seed of doubt is planted. Is Bethlehem violating one of the Laws of Eight? The men look at one another. Gibbs looks to Getty. Bethlehem looks from The Postman's tattoo to his face.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Where do I know you from?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: ‘Cry Havoc! And let slip the dogs of war.' Remember that?

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Shakespeare. The one who didn't want to fight.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I should've found a way to kill you then. But you seemed so strong.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Law seven it is. (to all) This war is settled here! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As The Postman nods in agreement. They take their positions -- and without a word -- they kick their horses into a charge. Coming straight for each other like medieval jousters. Bethlehem reaches for his sword. But before it clears the scabbard, The Postman lunges. The horses collide. Bethlehem and The Postman hit the ground hard. Holnists and Carriers alike begin to move forward for a better look. The fight is fierce. Bloody. The Postman and Bethlehem are at each other like coiled snakes. It's more of a fight than any of the Holnists -- especially Getty -- expected. The spectators pull in tighter. Both combatants have taken a beating -- and still, they fight on -- trading bloody, raw-knuckled punches. One of Bethlehem's connects. The Postman loses his footing, hits the ground -- knocking his head on a rock with a resounding CRACK. Dazed, he's slow to rise. It's just the moment Bethlehem needs, he straddles the fallen Postman, reaches for his knife with one hand -- grabs The Postman's throat with the other.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: I study people. I know your problem. Do you know why you can't fight? The Postman can't answer.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: You have nothing to fight for. You don't care about anything. You don't value anything. You don't believe in anything. That's what makes me better. The Postman grabs Bethlehem's knife-hand -- using all his remaining strength to keep him at bay.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (barely audible) I believe in the United States Postal Service. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman lets go of Bethlehem's hands, grabs his belt and pulls him over. As they roll to their feet, The Postman club-fists Bethlehem on the side of the head.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Neither snow... (wham! ) Nor rain... (wham! ) Nor heat... (wham! ) Nor gloom of night... (wham! ) Will stay this courier from the swift completion of his appointed rounds... Bethlehem reels, stumbling back. The Postman pounces on top of him, begins to strangle him. Bethlehem tries to pry the fingers from his throat, but can't. He's going to die. The Postman is urged on. By both sides. Holnists. Carriers. Ford. Even Holnist Luke. He looks up at the faces -- and finally lets Bethlehem go. The General gasps for breath. As Ponytail and Chubby move forward to untie Ford, The Postman looks to both sides.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: It doesn't have to be this way. We don't have to kill each other. We can live together. We can -- Ford takes Chubby's pistol, sets it against the side of Bethlehem's head.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Law three. Mercy is for the weak.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Ford, don't... Bethlehem shakes his head -- doesn't want him to, either.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Law eight. There is only one penalty and that penalty is death. Ford's going to shoot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: He isn't worth it. I'm the head of the clan now! There are going to be new laws! (to all) Law one! No more killing! There's going to be peace! The Postman looks at carriers and Holnists alike.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Who else? Who else has a law?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Everyone has to learn how to read.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: That's law two. Who else?!

dialogues.speaker: CARRIER
dialogues.text: Three. Liberty and justice for all!

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Four. No more tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIER
dialogues.text: Law five. Give peace a chance!

dialogues.speaker: HOLNIST SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Law six. Mercy is, it's okay sometimes!

dialogues.speaker: CARRIER
dialogues.text: Seven! Bring back vacations! The Postman nods solemnly, looks to Ford.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: How about it, Ford Lincoln Mercury? You give us law eight. Ford grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: (close -- for Ford) Be a leader, Ford.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Law eight... Ford FIRES! Bethlehem flinches, then sags as he realizes Ford has fired into the ground. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: --. Live and let live. The Postman smiles in relief as Ford lowers the revolver and starts to hand the weapon over. Forgotten for an instant, Bethlehem makes a last, wild lunge, grabs Ford's gun. As Bethlehem aims at The Postman, a SHOT rings out. Hit in the chest, Bethlehem blinks in amazement before he falls to the ground, dying. Getty has shot him.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: Would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing and bear-baiting. Oh, had I but followed the arts... He dies.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Grow like savages -- as soldiers will -- that nothing do but mediate on blood. Getty throws his rifle on the ground. Other weapons are laid down. The war, at long last, is over.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Somebody take a letter.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: A letter...

dialogues.speaker: INT. ABBY'S PLACE, (BRIDGE CITY)
dialogues.text: Abby, in bed, holding her new baby in her arms. She's reading a letter. What she reads makes her smile. She puts the letter down and cuddles her baby.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Your daddy wrote to tell you that he'll be here as soon as he can. And that he loves you very much. Abby looks up to see The Postman standing at her door. She looks at him, smiling with tears in her eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Mail's slow. I'1l have to see about that. Abby smiles down at the child in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Your daughter. Her name is Hope. The Postman takes the tiny child in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so my father returned home after the Holnists were defeated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beach town. No wall, no sentries, just cottages lining a dozen sand-swept streets. A crowd has gathered to hear The Postman's daughter, HOPE, mid-thirties, speak. Beside her, a bearded, 52-year-old Ford in his postmaster's uniform. They stand before a large, tarp-draped statue.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: But he never did see St. Rose. There was too much to be done. He'd made a promise and in keeping it -- he traded one dream for another. With no regrets. And so, in honor of my father... She unveils the statue: we've seen this before. It's The Postman on his horse, low-slung in the saddle, leaning down to pluck the letter from the Little Boy's hand. There's an OLDER MAN in the audience who seems especially moved by the statue. There's a younger man beside him.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: That was me. As St. Rose applauds... FADE OUT.
